entry.title: Fair Division 7 Ex-ante and Ex-post Fairness
entry.content:
Objective: Explore randomized indivisible allocations (equivalent to fractional allocation) and their implications on fairness: the compatibility of Ex-ante and Ex-post fairness.

Activities: Study the paper Best of Both Worlds: Ex-Ante and Ex-Post Fairness in Resource Allocation.

What does Both worlds here means?

The indivisible allocation is randomized.

  • Before the allocation, each agent has a expected valuation for the bundle. Ex-ante WORLD I

  • After the allocation, each agent has its actual valuation for the bundle. Ex-post WORLD II

Iannis told me to ignore anything related to GROUP FAIRNESS.

Indivisible goods, additive valuations.

When RANDOMIZATION is allowed, it is possible to achieve envy-freeness.

When allocation is deterministic, achieving exact fairness is impossible but approximate notions such as EF1 can be guaranteed.

Goal: Achieve both simultaneously by randomized allocation that is fair ex-ante and approximately fair ex-post.

Algorithm that achieves ex-ante EF with ex-post EF1.

ex-ante EF + ex-post EF1 + economic efficiency? impossible. ❌

ex-ante EF + relaxed ex-post fairness + economic efficiency? feasible. ✔️

Introduction

If we allowed to randomize, then we can choose an agent uniformly at random and allocate the entire set of goods. This is trivially ex-ante envy-free since all agents receive the same distribution.

ex-ante 可以理解为预期的，先验的

ex-post 可以理解为实施确定分配后的，后验的

However, this allocation induces a large amount of envy ex-post because there are times when one agent receives everything while others receive nothing.

Some ex-post envy is unavoidable: 2 agents, 1 item.

EF1 always exists, which limits the ex-post envy, but still be unfair if some agents are systematically favored over others.

Question: Can we randomize over EF1 allocations s.t. the resulting randomized allocation is EF? aka ex-ante EF + ex-post EF1.

本论文提出的期望无嫉妒和后验嫉妒特一物分配，即

  • 分配前：所有智能体获得的价值的期望是 EF 的

  • 分配后：所有智能体真实获得价值是 EF1 的

This paper: Yes.

Basic Results

en-ante\ex-postProp1+EF11EF1EF1+POEF1+fPO
Prop✔️✔️❓❌ Thm. 3
EF✔️✔️ Thm. 2❓❌
GF✔️ Cor. 1❌ Thm. 3❌❌

Algorithm: Recursive Probabilistic Serial, which produces an ex-ante EF distribution over deterministic allocation that each satisfy EF1.

Impossibility of ex-ante EF + ex-post EF1 + ex-ante PO.

But with relaxation of ex-post fairness, awe are able to achieve ex-ante group fairness (GF) (aka EF + PO), in conjunction with Prop1 or EF11 (envy-freeness up to one good more-and-less)

EF1⇒EF11,EF1⇒PROP1EF1\Rarr EF_1^1,EF1\Rarr PROP1EF1⇒EF11​,EF1⇒PROP1.

Related Work

Omitted

Preliminaries

Agent N=[n]N=[n]N=[n], Indivisible item M=[m]M=[m]M=[m].

Fractional and Randomized Allocations

Fractional allocation: for every item jjj, we have ∑i∈NAi,j≤1\sum_{i\in N}A_{i,j}\le1∑i∈N​Ai,j​≤1.

Complete allocation: a fractional allocation AAA satisfying ∀j∈M,∑i∈NAi,j=1\forall j\in M,\sum_{i\in N}A_{i,j}=1∀j∈M,∑i∈N​Ai,j​=1. Otherwise call it partial allocation.

Integral allocation: a fractional allocation if Ai,j∈{0,1}∀i∈N,j∈MA_{i,j}\in\{0,1\}\forall i\in N,j\in MAi,j​∈{0,1}∀i∈N,j∈M.

Let X\mathcal XX be all fractional allocations w.r.t. N,MN,MN,M.

Randomized allocation

X\mathbf XX, a lottery over integral allocations.

X\mathbf XX is specified by a set of ℓ∈N\ell\in\mathbb Nℓ∈N ordered pairs {(pk,Ak)}k∈[ℓ]\{(p^k,A^k)\}_{k\in[\ell]}{(pk,Ak)}k∈[ℓ]​.

AkA^kAk is an integral allocation implemented with probability pk∈[0,1]p^k\in[0,1]pk∈[0,1].

The support of X\mathbf XX is the set of integral allocations.

Preferences

gj≽igk⇔vi,j≥vi,kg_j\succcurlyeq_i g_k\Lrarr v_{i,j}\ge v_{i,k}gj​≽i​gk​⇔vi,j​≥vi,k​

gj≻igk⇔vi,j>vi,kg_j\succ_i g_k\Lrarr v_{i,j}\gt v_{i,k}gj​≻i​gk​⇔vi,j​>vi,k​

The utility of agent iii under X∈XX\in\mathcal XX∈X is vi(Xi)=∑j∈MXi,j⋅vi,jv_i(X_i)=\sum_{j\in M}X_{i,j}\cdot v_{i,j}vi​(Xi​)=∑j∈M​Xi,j​⋅vi,j​.

Allocation rule

f:I→2Xf:\mathcal I\rarr2^\mathcal Xf:I→2X

Fractional Maximum Nash Welfare Rule. Given an instance I∈II\in\mathcal II∈I, the fractional MNW returns all fractional allocations that maximize the product of agents’ utilities, i.e., MNW(I)=arg⁡max⁡X∈X∏i∈Nvi(Xi)MNW(I)=\arg\max_{X\in\mathcal X}\prod_{i\in N}v_i(X_i)MNW(I)=argmaxX∈X​∏i∈N​vi​(Xi​). We refer to an allocation A∈MNW(I)A\in MNW(I)A∈MNW(I) as a fractional MNW allocation.

Integral MNW allocation maximizes the product of agents’ utilities across all integral allocations.

Fairness and Efficiency Properties

PROP: Omitted

EF: Omitted

SD-EF: An allocation is SD-EF if for every pair of agents i,h∈Ni,h\in Ni,h∈N, we have Xi≽iSDXhX_i\succcurlyeq_i^{SD}X_hXi​≽iSD​Xh​

❗Xi≽iSDYiX_i\succcurlyeq_i^{SD}Y_iXi​≽iSD​Yi​ means agent iii is SD-prefers XiX_iXi​ to YiY_iYi​, if for every good g∈Mg\in Mg∈M, we have

∑gj∈{g′∈M:g′≽ig}Xi,j≥∑gj∈{g′∈M:g′≽ig}Yi,j\sum_{g_j\in\{g'\in M:g'\succcurlyeq_ig\}}X_{i,j}\ge\sum_{g_j\in\{g'\in M:g'\succcurlyeq_ig\}}Y_{i,j}gj​∈{g′∈M:g′≽i​g}∑​Xi,j​≥gj​∈{g′∈M:g′≽i​g}∑​Yi,j​

For example: 333 agents, 444 goods.

agent1:g1≽g2≽g3≽g4agent2:g2≽g3≽g4≽g1agent3:g3≽g4≽g1≽g2allocation X:Xg1g2g3g4120%30%20%10%230%50%30%40%340%20%50%50%allocation Y:Yg1g2g3g41100%00020100%00300100%100%agent_1:g_1\succcurlyeq g_2\succcurlyeq g_3\succcurlyeq g_4\\agent_2:g_2\succcurlyeq g_3\succcurlyeq g_4\succcurlyeq g_1\\agent_3:g_3\succcurlyeq g_4\succcurlyeq g_1\succcurlyeq g_2\\\text{allocation }X:\begin{array}{cc}X&g_1&g_2&g_3&g_4\\1&20\%&30\%&20\%&10\%\\2&30\%&50\%&30\%&40\%\\3&40\%&20\%&50\%&50\%\\\end{array}\\\text{allocation }Y:\begin{array}{cc}Y&g_1&g_2&g_3&g_4\\1&100\%&0&0&0\\2&0&100\%&0&0\\3&0&0&100\%&100\%\\\end{array}agent1​:g1​≽g2​≽g3​≽g4​agent2​:g2​≽g3​≽g4​≽g1​agent3​:g3​≽g4​≽g1​≽g2​allocation X:X123​g1​20%30%40%​g2​30%50%20%​g3​20%30%50%​g4​10%40%50%​allocation Y:Y123​g1​100%00​g2​0100%0​g3​00100%​g4​00100%​

Let’s take agent 111 as example:

  • for good g1g_1g1​: agent 111 gets 100%100\%100% in YYY, 20%20\%20% in XXX. iii SD-prefers YiY_iYi​ to XiX_iXi​ property holds w.r.t. g1g_1g1​ (100%≥0100\%\ge0100%≥0)

  • for good g2g_2g2​: agent 111 gets 100%100\%100% in YYY, 20%+30%=50%20\%+30\%=50\%20%+30%=50% in XXX. iii SD-prefers YiY_iYi​ to XiX_iXi​ property holds w.r.t. g2g_2g2​ (100%≥50%100\%\ge50\%100%≥50%)

  • for good g3g_3g3​: agent 111 gets 100%100\%100% in YYY, 20%+30%+20%=70%20\%+30\%+20\%=70\%20%+30%+20%=70% in XXX. iii SD-prefers YiY_iYi​ to XiX_iXi​ property holds w.r.t. g3g_3g3​ (100%≥70%100\%\ge70\%100%≥70%)

  • for good g4g_4g4​: agent 111 gets 100100%100 in YYY, (20+30+20+10)%=80%(20+30+20+10)\%=80\%(20+30+20+10)%=80% in XXX. iii SD-prefers YiY_iYi​ to XiX_iXi​ property holds w.r.t. g4g_4g4​.

    THUS, IN THIS CASE, AGENT iii SD-PREFERS YiY_iYi​ TO XiX_iXi​.

SD abbr. for first-order Stochastic Dominance.

EF⇒SD−EFEF\Rarr SD-EFEF⇒SD−EF

fPO and PO: Omitted

🤔Proposition 1. If a randomized allocation is ex-ante PO, then it is also ex-post fPO.

If a randomized allocation X={(pk,Ak)}k∈[ℓ]\mathbf X=\{(p^k,A^k)\}_{k\in[\ell]}X={(pk,Ak)}k∈[ℓ]​ implementing a fractional allocation XXX is not ex-post fPO, then for some k∈[ℓ]k\in[\ell]k∈[ℓ], integral allocation AkA^kAk must be Pareto dominated by a fractional allocation, say YYY. Then the fractional allocation X′=pk⋅Y+∑r≠kpr⋅ArX'=p^k\cdot Y+\sum_{r\neq k}p^r\cdot A^rX′=pk⋅Y+∑r=k​pr⋅Ar Pareto-dominates XXX, which implies that X\mathbf XX is not ex-ante PO.

Group Fairness (GF). An allocation XXX is group fair if for all non-empty subsets of agents S,T⊆NS,T\subseteq NS,T⊆N, there is no fractional allocation YYY of ∪i∈TXi\cup_{i\in T}X_i∪i∈T​Xi​ to the agents in SSS s.t. ∣S∣∣T∣⋅vi(Yi)≥vi(Xi)\frac{|S|}{|T|}\cdot v_i(Y_i)\ge v_i(X_i)∣T∣∣S∣​⋅vi​(Yi​)≥vi​(Xi​) for all i∈Si\in Si∈S and at least one inequality is strict.

❗By imposing constraints on (S,T)(S,T)(S,T) pair can recover properties such as PROP (∣S∣=1,T=N)(|S|=1,T=N)(∣S∣=1,T=N), EF (∣S∣=∣T∣=1)(|S|=|T|=1)(∣S∣=∣T∣=1) and fPO (S=T=N)(S=T=N)(S=T=N).

PROP1, EF1: Omitted

SD-Envy-Freeness up to One Good (SD-EF1). An integral allocation is SD-EF1 if for every pair of agents i,h∈Ni,h\in Ni,h∈N s.t. Ah≠∅A_h\neq\emptyAh​=∅, we have Ai≽iSDAh╲{j}A_i\succcurlyeq_i^{SD}A_h\diagdown\{j\}Ai​≽iSD​Ah​╲{j} for some good j∈Ahj\in A_hj∈Ah​.

(This is equivalent to agent iii not envying agent hhh up to one good under every additive valuation consistent with the ordinal preference relation ≽i\succcurlyeq_i≽i​)

Envy-Freeness up to One Good More-and-Less (EF11). An integral allocation AAA is EF11 if for every pair of agents i,h∈Ni,h\in Ni,h∈N s.t. Ah≠∅A_h\neq\emptyAh​=∅, we have vi(Ai∪{ji})≥vi(Ah╲{jh})v_i(A_i\cup\{j_i\})\ge v_i(A_h\diagdown\{j_h\})vi​(Ai​∪{ji​})≥vi​(Ah​╲{jh​}) for some goods ji∉Aij_i\not\in A_iji​∈Ai​ and jh∈Ahj_h\in A_hjh​∈Ah​.

Relations:

SD−EF1⇒EF1⇒{EF11PROP1SD-EF1\Rarr EF1\Rarr\begin{cases}EF_1^1\\PROP1\end{cases}SD−EF1⇒EF1⇒{EF11​PROP1​

Possibility: Ex-ante EF + Ex-post EF1

Ex-ante EF + Ex-post EF1 can be achieved simultaneously.

Based on round-robin, with manipulation of agent order. Uniformly randomizing the agent ordering also achieves ex-ante proportionality.

🤔Proposition 2. With additive valuations, randomized round-robin is ex-ante PROP and ex-post EF1.

Obviously, randomized round-robin is ex-post EF1. For ex-ante PROP, fix an agent iii, and suppose, without loss of generality, that vi,1≥vi,2≥⋯≥vi,mv_{i,1}\ge v_{i,2}\ge\cdots\ge v_{i,m}vi,1​≥vi,2​≥⋯≥vi,m​. Suppose m=cnm=cnm=cn for some positive integer ccc.

When agent iii is kkk-th in the ordering, her value for her allocation is at least vi,k+vi,k+n+⋯+vi,k+(c−1)n=∑c′=1cvi,(c′−1)n+kv_{i,k}+v_{i,k+n}+\cdots+v_{i,k+(c-1)n}=\sum_{c'=1}^cv_{i,(c'-1)n+k}vi,k​+vi,k+n​+⋯+vi,k+(c−1)n​=∑c′=1c​vi,(c′−1)n+k​ because the c′c'c′-th good she chooses must be no less preferred than her (c′−1)n+k(c'-1)n+k(c′−1)n+k-th most preferred good.

Since she appears in every position in the ordering with probability 1/n1/n1/n, her expected value is at least 1n∑k=1m∑c′=1cvi,(c′−1)n+k=1n∑j=1mgi,j\frac{1}{n}\sum_{k=1}^m\sum_{c'=1}^cv_{i,(c'-1)n+k}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{j=1}^mg_{i,j}n1​∑k=1m​∑c′=1c​vi,(c′−1)n+k​=n1​∑j=1m​gi,j​, which matches her proportionality guarantee.

However, just by randomizing agent order, sometimes we fail to achieve ex-ante EF. Example omitted.

Noted that there are n!n!n! possible agent orders. For iii, some orders may better than the others.

Instead of starting from a method that guarantees ex-post EF1 and using it to achieve ex-ante EF, we do the opposite: Start from a fractional EF allocation and implement it using integral EF1 allocations.

Probabilistic serial is an algorithm that produces a fractional EF allocations.

  • serial eating protocol wherein all agents simultaneously start eating their respective favorite goods at the same constant speed.
  • Once a good is completely consumed by a subset of agents, each of those agents proceeds to eating her favorite available good at the same speed.
  • The algorithm terminates when all goods have been eaten, and fraction of each good consumed by an agent is allocated to her.

A very vivid algorithm

A useful property of this algorithm: it only uses the ordinal preferences of agents over goods, and computes an allocation that is ex-ante envy-free for any additive utilities consistent with the ordinal preferences. Thus, it’s SD-EF.

Use a variant of probabilistic serial, recursive probabilistic serial, which provides the desired fairness guarantees, i.e., ex-ante EF and ex-post EF1.

Recursive Probabilistic Serial

Given as input a subset of goods M′⊆MM'\subseteq MM′⊆M, the algorithm allows each agent to consume its favorite available good in M′M'M′ out of those that have not yet been fully consumed at a rate of one good per unit time.

Let Xt=eating(M′,t)X^t=eating(M',t)Xt=eating(M′,t) denote the partial allocation obtained when the algorithm is run for ttt unit of time. Note that eating(M,⌈mn⌉)eating(M,\lceil\frac{m}{n}\rceil)eating(M,⌈nm​⌉) is equivalent to the outcome of the probabilistic serial algorithm.

🎯🤔Theorem 1. (Brikhoff-von Neumann) Let XXX be a real-valued n×mn\times mn×m matrix s.t.

  1. X_{ij}\in[0,1]\forall i\in[n]\and j\in[m]
  2. ∑j=1mXij≤1∀i∈[n]\sum_{j=1}^mX_{ij}\le1\forall i\in[n]∑j=1m​Xij​≤1∀i∈[n]
  3. ∑i=1nXij≤1∀j∈[m]\sum_{i=1}^nX_{ij}\le1\forall j\in[m]∑i=1n​Xij​≤1∀j∈[m]

Then, in strongly polynomial time, one can compute integral matrices A1,A2,⋯ ,AqA^1,A^2,\cdots,A^qA1,A2,⋯,Aq and weights w1,w2,⋯ ,wq∈[0,1]w^1,w^2,\cdots,w^q\in[0,1]w1,w2,⋯,wq∈[0,1] s.t.

  1. ∑k=1qwk=1\sum_{k=1}^qw^k=1∑k=1q​wk=1 and X=∑k=1qwkAkX=\sum_{k=1}^qw^kA^kX=∑k=1q​wkAk
  2. For each integral matrix AkA^kAk, we have A^k_{ij}\in\{0,1\}\forall i\in[n]\and j\in[m]
  3. For every k∈[q]k\in[q]k∈[q], we have
    • ⌊∑j=1mXij⌋≤∑j=1mAijk≤⌈∑j=1mXij⌉\lfloor\sum_{j=1}^mX_{ij}\rfloor\le\sum_{j=1}^mA^k_{ij}\le\lceil\sum_{j=1}^mX_{ij}\rceil⌊∑j=1m​Xij​⌋≤∑j=1m​Aijk​≤⌈∑j=1m​Xij​⌉
    • ⌊∑i=1nXij⌋≤∑i=1nAijk≤⌈∑i=1nXij⌉\lfloor\sum_{i=1}^nX_{ij}\rfloor\le\sum_{i=1}^nA^k_{ij}\le\lceil\sum_{i=1}^nX_{ij}\rceil⌊∑i=1n​Xij​⌋≤∑i=1n​Aijk​≤⌈∑i=1n​Xij​⌉

The algorithm proceeds in stages. In each stages, the EATING procedure is run for one unit of time, after which every agent has consumed a total mass of one item.

Then, by theorem 1, this fractional partial allocation can be decomposed into integral allocations. By 3. of theorem 1, each agent receives exactly one item in each integral allocation in the support.

We interpret the weights w1,⋯ ,wqw^1,\cdots,w^qw1,⋯,wq as probabilities, and sample an integral allocation from this distribution before proceeding to the next stage.

The algorithm then fixes the assignments of the goods to the agents in accordance with the aforementioned integral partial allocation, and repeats the eating procedure with the reduced set of goods.

In the final stage of the algorithm, fewer than nnn goods might remain, in which case some agents do not receive any good under the integral allocation. The full procedure is describe in pseudo code.

Pseudo-code of Algorithm 1

Ex-ante EF + ex-post EF1

  1. B←(∅,⋯ ,∅)B\gets(\empty,\cdots,\empty)B←(∅,⋯,∅)
  2. M0←MM^0\gets MM0←M
  3. for t=1t=1t=1 to ⌈mn⌉\lceil\frac{m}{n}\rceil⌈nm​⌉ do
    • Xt←X^t\getsXt← eating(Mt,1)(M^t,1)(Mt,1) // eating protocol for one unit of time
    • BvN: Xt=∑k=1ℓwt,kAt,kX^t=\sum_{k=1}^\ell w^{t,k}A^{t,k}Xt=∑k=1ℓ​wt,kAt,k // decomposition from theorem 1
    • Bt←At,kB^t\gets A^{t,k}Bt←At,k with probability wt,kw^{t,k}wt,k // sampling step
    • Mt+1←Mt╲⋃i∈NBitM^{t+1}\gets M^t\diagdown\bigcup_{i\in N}B_i^tMt+1←Mt╲⋃i∈N​Bit​ // fix the assignments according to the sampled allocation
    • Bi←Bi⋃t=1⌈mn⌉BitB_i\gets B_i\bigcup_{t=1}^{\lceil\frac{m}{n}\rceil}B_i^tBi​←Bi​⋃t=1⌈nm​⌉​Bit​ for all i∈Ni\in Ni∈N // update integral allocation
  4. return BBB

Every integral allocation returned by Algorithm 1 satisfies EF1.

🤔Lemma 1. Let t<⌈mn⌉t\lt\lceil\frac{m}{n}\rceilt<⌈nm​⌉. Let gi,tg_{i,t}gi,t​ denote the good allocated to agent iii in iteration ttt of Algorithm 1. Then agent iii weakly prefers gi,tg_{i,t}gi,t​ to all goods in Mt+1M^{t+1}Mt+1 (goods unallocated after ttt iterations of the algorithm).

Proof by contradiction.

If there exists a good g∗∈Mt+1g^*\in M^{t+1}g∗∈Mt+1 s.t. vi(g∗)>vi(gi,t)v_i(g^*)\gt v_i(g_{i,t})vi​(g∗)>vi​(gi,t​), then by theorem 1, agent iii must have eaten a non-zero share of good gi,tg_{i,t}gi,t​ in iteration ttt. On the other hand, g∗∈Mt+1g^*\in M^{t+1}g∗∈Mt+1 implies that g∗∈Mtg^*\in M^tg∗∈Mt, and thus g∗g^*g∗ must not be fully consumed in iteration ttt. However, since gi(g∗)>vi(g)g_i(g^*)\gt v_i(g)gi​(g∗)>vi​(g), agent iii should have then consumed g∗g^*g∗ before consuming gi,tg_{i,t}gi,t​ in iteration ttt, which is a contradiction.

🤔Lemma 2. Every integral allocation returned by Algorithm 1 satisfies EF1.

∀i∈[n]\forall i\in[n]∀i∈[n], let gi,tg_{i,t}gi,t​ denote the good received by agent iii in iteration ttt. Fix a pair of agents i,k∈Ni,k\in Ni,k∈N. By lemma 1, for every t<⌈mn⌉t\lt\lceil\frac{m}{n}\rceilt<⌈nm​⌉, we have vi(gi,t)≥vi(gk,t+1)v_i(g_{i,t})\ge v_i(g_{k,t+1})vi​(gi,t​)≥vi​(gk,t+1​) because gk,t+1∈Mt+1g_{k,t+1}\in M^{t+1}gk,t+1​∈Mt+1. Hence,

vi(Ai)≥∑i=1⌈mn⌉−1vi(gi,t)≥∑i=2⌈mn⌉vi(gi,t)=vi(Ak╲{gk,1})v_i(A_i)\ge\sum_{i=1}^{\lceil\frac{m}{n}\rceil-1}v_i(g_{i,t})\ge\sum_{i=2}^{\lceil\frac{m}{n}\rceil}v_i(g_{i,t})=v_i(A_k\diagdown\{g_{k,1}\})vi​(Ai​)≥i=1∑⌈nm​⌉−1​vi​(gi,t​)≥i=2∑⌈nm​⌉​vi​(gi,t​)=vi​(Ak​╲{gk,1​})

which establishes EF1.

🎯🤔Theorem 2. The randomized allocation implemented by algorithm 1 is ex-ante EF + ex-post EF1.

By lemma, it is indeed ex-post EF1.

Notice that each agent eats her preferred available good at each point in time during the eating algorithm. Therefore, for any iteration ttt, the partial fractional allocation XtX^tXt computed by the eating procedure in iteration ttt is EF.

The rest is induction.

Since Recursive Probabilistic Serial takes only the ordinal references of agents over goods as input, thus it is in fact ex-ante SD-EF + ex-post SD-EF1.

A Polynomial-Time Algorithm for Ex-ante EF + Ex-post EF1

Full randomized allocation constructed by Algorithm 1 require exponential time.

Approach to reducing the support size is to use the Carathéodory’s theorem from convex analysis: If a point x∈Rdx\in\mathbb R^dx∈Rd lies in the convex hull of a set PPP, then xxx can be expressed as a convex combination of at most d+1d+1d+1 vertices of PPP.

Any fractional allocation XXX is a point in an n×mn\times mn×m-dimensional space. By Carathéodory’s theorem, if it is a convex combination of integral allocations in the support {A1,⋯ ,Aℓ}\{A^1,\cdots,A^\ell\}{A1,⋯,Aℓ}, then it can also be written as a convex combination of at most nm+1nm+1nm+1 allocations from this set.

This establishes the existence of a convex combination with small support, it does not automatically provide an efficient algorithm for converting a convex combination with large support to one with small support.

In the modification of recursive probabilistic serial, we ensure that the support size remains mn+1mn+1mn+1 after every step of “branching out”.

Every step of branching out can increase the support size of mn+1mn+1mn+1 to (nm+1)⋅p(m,n)(nm+1)\cdot p(m,n)(nm+1)⋅p(m,n). Thus we need a way to reduce the support size from at most (mn+1)⋅p(m,n)(mn+1)\cdot p(m,n)(mn+1)⋅p(m,n) to at most nm+1nm+1nm+1.

🤔Proposition 3. There is a polynomial-time algorithm, that given a polytope P\mathcal PP with a strong separation oracle and a point y∈Py\in\mathcal Py∈P, returns a representation of yyy as a convex combination of dim⁡(P)+1\dim(\mathcal P)+1dim(P)+1 vertices of P\mathcal PP.

Notice that at the end of the first iteration t=1t=1t=1, the fractional partial allocation X1X^1X1 consists of a polynomial number of integral allocations in its support, i.e., X1=∑k=1ℓw1,kA1,kX^1=\sum_{k=1}^\ell w^{1,k}A^{1,k}X1=∑k=1ℓ​w1,kA1,k, where ℓ=p(m,n)\ell=p(m,n)ℓ=p(m,n) for some polynomial ppp. Consider the polytope P1\mathcal P^1P1 formed by the convex hull of the integral allocations A1,1,⋯ ,A1,ℓA^{1,1},\cdots,A^{1,\ell}A1,1,⋯,A1,ℓ as follows

\mathcal P^1=\{z:z=\sum_k\alpha_kA^{1,k}\text{ where }(\alpha_k\ge0\forall k\in[\ell])\and(\sum_k\alpha_k=1)\}

polytope 多胞体

  1. Convexity: A polytope is a convex set, meaning that for any two points inside the polytope, the line segment connecting them lies entirely within the polytope.
  2. Finite Set of Vertices: A polytope is defined by a finite set of vertices (or corners) in Euclidean space. These vertices are the extreme points of the polytope and determine its shape.
  3. Higher-Dimensional Analogues: Just as a polygon is a two-dimensional polytope and a polyhedron is a three-dimensional polytope, polytopes can exist in any finite number of dimensions. For example, a four-dimensional polytope is called a polytope, and a five-dimensional polytope is called a polychoron.
  4. Faces: The faces of a polytope are the lower-dimensional subsets of the polytope that are themselves polytopes. For example, in a three-dimensional polyhedron, the faces are the polygons that form its surface.
  5. Simplexes and Polygons: Simplexes are special types of polytopes that are defined as the convex hull of a set of affinely independent points. A simplex in two dimensions is a triangle, and in three dimensions, it is a tetrahedron. Polygons are also considered special cases of polytopes.

Observe that P1\mathcal P^1P1 admits a polynomial-time strong separation oracle. One can decide in polynomial time whether a given point y∈Rn×my\in\mathbb R^{n\times m}y∈Rn×m belongs to P1\mathcal P^1P1, or return a separating hyper-plane if it doesn’t. This implies that an (nm+1)(nm+1)(nm+1)-sized decomposition of X1X^1X1, as guaranteed by Carathéodory’s theorem can be computed in polynomial time.

Having computed an (nm+1)(nm+1)(nm+1)-sized decomposition of X1X^1X1, we obtain at most nm+1nm+1nm+1 sub-instances in each of which we re-run algorithm. Notice that this result in a probability distribution over (nm+1)⋅p(n,m)(nm+1)\cdot p(n,m)(nm+1)⋅p(n,m) deterministic allocations at the end of the second iteration. Re-invoke algorithmic version of Carathéodory’s theorem to obtain a decomposition over at most mn+1mn+1mn+1 of these integral allocations in polynomial time.

Produced randomized allocation has support that is a subset of the support of the randomized allocation produced by recursive probabilistic serial. Hence, ex-post EF1 of this modified procedure follows immediately from lemma 1.

Like algorithm 1, this algorithm produces the same ex-ante SD-EF + ex-post SD-EF1.

Impossibility: ex-ante PROP + ex-post EF1 + ex-post fPO

The previous lacks efficiency.

ex-ante PO ⇒\Rarr⇒ ex-post fPO ⇒\Rarr⇒ ex-post PO

ex-ante EF + ex-post PO + ex-post EF1? Not solve…

How about stronger one, ex-post fPO? The answer is negative for ex-ante PROP + ex-post EF1 + ex-post fPO.

🎯🤔Theorem 3. There exists an instance with additive valuations in which no randomized allocation is simultaneously ex-ante PROP + ex-post EF1 + ex-post fPO.

It suffices to give an instance with unique EF1 + fPO allocation which violates PROP.

2 goods g1,g2g_1,g_2g1​,g2​, 2 agent a1,a2a_1,a_2a1​,a2​ with valuations

g1g_1g1​g2g_2g2​
a1a_1a1​12
a2a_2a2​13

This instance has exactlly 2 integral EF1 allocations: A=({g1},{g2})A=(\{g_1\},\{g_2\})A=({g1​},{g2​}) and B=({g2},{g1})B=(\{g_2\},\{g_1\})B=({g2​},{g1​}). It’s easy to check that BBB is not fPO, since it is Pareto dominated by a fractional allocation XXX that assign g1g_1g1​ to a1a_1a1​ and splits g2g_2g2​ equally between 2 agents.

AAA is fPO, maximizing the utilitarian social welfare.

Observe that AAA violates PROP since v1(A1)=v1(g1)<12v1(g1∪g2)v_1(A_1)=v_1(g_1)\lt\frac{1}{2}v_1(g_1\cup g_2)v1​(A1​)=v1​(g1​)<21​v1​(g1​∪g2​).

Additionally, ex-ante EF and ex-ante GF imply ex-ante PROP, thus these are also incompatible with ex-post EF1 + PO.

Since ex-ante PO implies ex-post fPO, thus ex-ante (PROP + PO) and ex-ante (EF + PO) are incompatible with ex-post EF1.

Possibility: ex-ante GF + ex-post PROP1 + ex-post EF11

Omitted

Characterizing MNW

Seems related to GF, can be omitted.

The Case of Bads

“Bads” here means chores. aka all items are negative valued.

Let MMM be set of mmm bads. Fractional, integral and randomized allocations are defined analogously as in the case of goods.

However the agents have non-positive valuation functions. There are differences when defining fairness notions.

PROP1, aka proportionality up to one bad. An integral allocation AAA is PROP1 if for every agent iii, either vi(Ai)≥vi(M)/nv_i(A_i)\ge v_i(M)/nvi​(Ai​)≥vi​(M)/n or there exists a bad j∈Aij\in A_ij∈Ai​ s.t. vi(Ai╲{j})≥vi(M)/nv_i(A_i\diagdown\{j\})\ge v_i(M)/nvi​(Ai​╲{j})≥vi​(M)/n, where vi(M)v_i(M)vi​(M) is iii’s valuation for all bads.

EFk, aka envy-freeness up to kkk bads. An integral allocation AAA is EFk if for every pair of agent i,hi,hi,h, there ∃Si⊆Ai\exist S_i\subseteq A_i∃Si​⊆Ai​ with ∣Si∣≤k|S_i|\le k∣Si​∣≤k s.t. vi(Ai╲Si)≥vi(Ah)v_i(A_i\diagdown S_i)\ge v_i(A_h)vi​(Ai​╲Si​)≥vi​(Ah​).

EF11, aka envy-freeness up to one bad more-and-less. An integral allocation AAA is EF11 if for every pair of agent i,hi,hi,h s.t. Ai≠∅A_i\neq\emptyAi​=∅, we have vi(Ai╲{ji})≥vi(Ah∪{jh})v_i(A_i\diagdown\{j_i\})\ge v_i(A_h\cup\{j_h\})vi​(Ai​╲{ji​})≥vi​(Ah​∪{jh​}) for some bads ji∈Aij_i\in A_iji​∈Ai​ and jh∉Ahj_h\not\in A_hjh​∈Ah​.

Ex-ante EF + Ex-post EF1 for Bads

Recursive Probabilistic Serial and its polynomial-time variant only use ordinal preferences of agents over goods.

Problem here: Can we construct an ordinal preference over bads in which the bads are sorted in a non-increasing order of the agent’s valuation for them.

Both RPS and its polynomial-time variant are always ex-post EF2 for bads.

🤔Proposition 6. For additive valuation functions over bads, recursive probabilistic serial and its polynomial variant produce randomized allocation that are ex-ante EF and ex-post EF2.

eating procedure is EF because agents are forced to eat bads at the same rate and an agent is always eating a bad that she prefers the most among all bads not fully consumed.

Since each XtX^tXt is EF, a probability distribution over XtX^tXt in different branches is also envy-free. Hence, the expected fractional allocation induced in step ttt is EF for each ttt. Hence, ex-ante EF.

For ex-post EF2, let AAA be an integral allocation produced by RPS. By lemma 1 still holds for bads.

For t<⌈m/n⌉t\lt\lceil m/n\rceilt<⌈m/n⌉, if bi,tb_{i,t}bi,t​ denotes the bad allocated to agent iii in iteration ttt, then agent iii prefers bi,tb_{i,t}bi,t​ to all bads in Mt+1M^{t+1}Mt+1.

When t<⌊m/n⌋t\lt\lfloor m/n \rfloort<⌊m/n⌋, we know that another agent hhh must receive a bad in round t+1≤⌊m/n⌋t+1\le\lfloor m/n \rfloort+1≤⌊m/n⌋. Hence, for all agents i,h∈Ni,h\in Ni,h∈N and all t<⌊m/n⌋t\lt\lfloor m/n\rfloort<⌊m/n⌋, we have vi(bi,t)≥vi(bh,t+1)v_i(b_{i,t})\ge v_i(b_{h,t+1})vi​(bi,t​)≥vi​(bh,t+1​).

Summing over t<⌊m/n⌋t\lt\lfloor m/n\rfloort<⌊m/n⌋, we get

vi({bi,t:1≤t<⌊m/n⌋})≥vi({bh,t:2≤t≤⌊m/n⌋})≥vi(Ah)v_i(\lbrace b_{i,t}:1\le t\lt\lfloor m/n\rfloor\rbrace)\ge v_i(\lbrace b_{h,t}:2\le t\le\lfloor m/n\rfloor\rbrace)\ge v_i(A_h)vi​({bi,t​:1≤t<⌊m/n⌋})≥vi​({bh,t​:2≤t≤⌊m/n⌋})≥vi​(Ah​)

In the LHS, there are at most 2 bads missing from AiA_iAi​:

  • The bad allocated to agent iii in round ⌊m/n⌋\lfloor m/n\rfloor⌊m/n⌋
  • Tge bad which may be allocated tot agent iii in the final round ⌈m/n⌉\lceil m/n\rceil⌈m/n⌉

Q.E.D.

Naturally, the algorithm also produces ex-ante SD-EF + ex-post SD-EF2.

When mmm is a multiple of nnn, it turns out that the allocation is in fact ex-post EF1.

🤔Lemma 5. For additive valuation functions over bads, recursive probabilistic serial and its polynomial-time variant from Section 3.2 produce randomized allocations that are ex-ante envy-free (EF) and ex-post envy-free up to one bad (EF1) whenever the number of bads is divisible by the number of agents.

Proof by proposition 6.

If nnn divides mmm, we guarantee that there is only one bad missing from the LHS, which is that allocated to agent iii in round m/nm/nm/n.

Simple modification of RPS, simply add a number of “dummy bads” which all agent value at 000 s.t. the total number of bads becomes divisible by the number of nnn, then run RPS to compute ex-ante EF + ex-post EF1.

🎯🤔Theorem 6. For additive valuation over bads, there always exists a randomized allocation that is ex-ante EF + ex-post EF1 which can be computed in polynomial time.

What about fair division of mixed manna?

Each item can be either a good or a bad for each agent.

EF1 can be generalized to the mixed manna setting. It requires that if iii envies hhh, then the envy can be eliminated by either removing one item from agent hhh’s bundle (which must be a good for iii), or one item from agent iii’s bundle (which must be a bad for iii).

EF1 aka envy-freeness up to one item. An integral allocation AAA is EF1 if for every pair of agent i,hi,hi,h, either iii does not envy hhh, or there exists an item o∈Ai∪Aho\in A_i\cup A_ho∈Ai​∪Ah​ s.t. vi(Ai╲{o})≥vi(Ah╲{o})v_i(A_i\diagdown\{o\})\ge v_i(A_h\diagdown\{o\})vi​(Ai​╲{o})≥vi​(Ah​╲{o}).

The algorithm of this paper achieve the relaxation of EF1 in mixed manna setting, w-EF1.

w-EF1 aka weak envy-freeness up to one item. An integral allocation AAA is w-EF1 if for every pair i,hi,hi,h, either iii does not envy hhh, or there exists a good oh∈Aho_h\in A_hoh​∈Ah​ and/or a bad oi∈Aio_i\in A_ioi​∈Ai​ s.t. vi(Ai╲{oi})≥vi(Ah╲{oh})v_i(A_i\diagdown\{o_i\})\ge v_i(A_h\diagdown\{o_h\})vi​(Ai​╲{oi​})≥vi​(Ah​╲{oh​}).

🎯🤔Theorem 7. For additive valuation in the mixed manna setting, there always exists a randomized algorithm producing ex-ante EF + ex-post w-EF1, which can be computed in polynomial time.

Add dummy items to guarantee that mmm is a integer multiple of nnn, and remove them at the end.

When we run RPS on such instance, we can again apply the same argument as in the proof in proposition 6. That is equivalent to ex-post w-EF1 guarantee.

Of course, this results is also ex-ante SD-EF and ex-post SD-w-EF1 for mixed manna.

Ex-ante GF + Ex-post PROP1 + Ex-post EF11 for Bads

Omitted

Discussion

❓Open question:

  • ex-ante PROP + ex-post (EF1 + PO)
  • ex-ante EF + ex-post (EF1 + PO)

Difficulty: hard to analyze the methods of finding EF1 + PO allocations.

❓Open question:

  • Does there always exist an integral EF1 + PO allocation in which agent iii doesn’t envy agent jjj?
  • What about an integral EF1 + PO allocation in which agent iii does not envy any other agent?
  • Given a priority ordering over the agents, does there always exist an EF1 + PO allocation in which no agent envies an agent with lower priority?

Other possible work direction: EFX/MMS for ex-post fairness?

How about ex-ante and ex-post fairness guarantees in voting, matching and public decision-making?

entry.title: 丹麦语 DU 3.2 9-10 Arbejde og studieliv
entry.content:
er ansat af 受雇于

borger -en -ere- erne 公民

rækkefølge -n -r -rne 顺序

det værste 最坏的事

især 副词，尤其是

deltid 兼职

fuldtid 全职

Modultest DU 3.2 模拟题阅读部分

Opgave 1

是类似于中考英语的弱智题，直接可以找原文。注意用短回答 kortsvar，不要给自己加戏！

Opgave 2

我认为阅读部分最 SVÆRT 的题目，给五段话，每段话有一个句子不符合段落大意，需要划掉。因为生词太多了，根本读不懂！

一种投机取巧的方式：每段话都选择最短的那个句子划掉。大概 80% 的情况下这样做答案是对的。

老师说，要做好这题，必须多读多积累单词😭

hjort -en -e -ene 鹿

springe ud 跳到跟前；保释

flyvende 飞行的 adj

mørk 黑暗的 adj

falde i søvn 入睡

pludselig 突然 adj

ramme 击打；撞到

sikkerhedssele -n -r -rne 安全带

Ingen blev skadet. 没人受伤。

alligevel 然而 adv

forskrække -r -de -t 害怕

生词太多了，烦死了

Opgave 3

选词填空，不涉及词性变换，理解题意，通读几遍，正确率不会太低。

Opgave 4

给五段陈述，对五个题干表述进行匹配。

Aktiviteter og steder på studiet

forelæsning -en -er -erne 讲座

undervisning -en -er -erne 课堂（相对于 forelæsning 而言，互动更多）

fremlægge -r -…lagde -…lagt 展示，演讲，present

indsamle -r -de -t 收集

mødelokale -t -r -rne 会议室

beregne -r -de -t 计算

dissekere -r -de -r 解剖，剖析

entry.title: 数据挖掘 11 Frequent Subgraph Mining
entry.content:
A labeled graph is a triple G=(V,E,ℓ)G=(V,E,\ell)G=(V,E,ℓ) where ℓ:V∪E→L\ell:V\cup E\rarr Lℓ:V∪E→L is a labeling function assigning a label from a set of labels LLL to each node and each edge.

Definition of frequency: it is encoded into a support measure that return the number of occurrences of the subgraph in the graph.

FSM in Graph Collections

A graph collection aka a graph database is a set D={G1,G2,⋯ ,Gn}\mathcal D=\{G_1,G_2,\cdots,G_n\}D={G1​,G2​,⋯,Gn​} of labeled graphs Gi=(Vi,Vi,ℓi),i∈[1,n]G_i=(V_i,V_i,\ell_i),i\in[1,n]Gi​=(Vi​,Vi​,ℓi​),i∈[1,n].

Since a subgraph is uniquely identified by the nodes and edges of a certain graph, we need to relax the definition, so that it counts the occurrences of that subgraph in different graphs.

A graph G1(V1,E1,ℓ1)G_1(V_1,E_1,\ell_1)G1​(V1​,E1​,ℓ1​) is isomorphic 同构 to a graph G2=(V2,E2,ℓ2)G_2=(V_2,E_2,\ell_2)G2​=(V2​,E2​,ℓ2​) if there exists a bijective function f:V1→V2f:V_1\rarr V_2f:V1​→V2​ such that if u∈V1u\in V_1u∈V1​ then f(u)∈V2f(u)\in V_2f(u)∈V2​ and ℓ1(u)=ℓ2(f(u))\ell_1(u)=\ell_2(f(u))ℓ1​(u)=ℓ2​(f(u)) and if (u,v)∈E1(u,v)\in E_1(u,v)∈E1​ then (f(u),f(v))∈E2(f(u),f(v))\in E_2(f(u),f(v))∈E2​ and ℓ1((u,v))=ℓ2((f(u),f(v)))\ell_1((u,v))=\ell_2((f(u),f(v)))ℓ1​((u,v))=ℓ2​((f(u),f(v))).

If a graph G1G_1G1​ is isomorphic to a subgraph of another graph GGG, we say G1G_1G1​ is subgraph isomorphic to GGG. Subgraph isomorphism is NP-complete, which graph isomorphism is NP.

Denote: G⊑G1G\sqsubseteq G_1G⊑G1​ a subgraph isomorphism from GGG to G1G_1G1​.

Given a collection of graphs D={G1,G2,⋯ ,Gn}\mathcal D=\{G_1,G_2,\cdots,G_n\}D={G1​,G2​,⋯,Gn​} and a graph GGG, the support set DG\mathcal D_GDG​ is the subset of D\mathcal DD, s.t. GGG is subgraph isomorphic to every graph in G′∈DGG'\in\mathcal D_GG′∈DG​, i.e., DG={G′∈D∣G⊑G′}\mathcal D_G=\{G'\in\mathcal D|G\sqsubseteq G'\}DG​={G′∈D∣G⊑G′}. The support sup⁡(G)\sup(G)sup(G) of GGG is the proportion σ(G)=∣DG∣∣D∣\sigma(G)=\frac{|\mathcal D_G|}{|\mathcal D|}σ(G)=∣D∣∣DG​∣​.

The Frequent Subgraph Mining FSM problem in collection of graphs D={G1,G2,⋯ ,Gn}\mathcal D=\{G_1,G_2,\cdots,G_n\}D={G1​,G2​,⋯,Gn​} finds all the subgraphs GGG having at least support min⁡sup⁡\min\supminsup, i.e., σ(G)≥min⁡sup⁡\sigma(G)\ge\min\supσ(G)≥minsup.

Downward Closure Property

  • Downward closure is the property under which a support measure decreases by expanding a pattern. In particular in our case sup⁡(G)≤sup⁡(G′)\sup(G)\le\sup(G')sup(G)≤sup(G′) if G′⊑GG'\sqsubseteq GG′⊑G.

The downward closure property leads to 2 different family of approaches: apriori-based approaches and pattern-growth approaches.

Apriori-based Approaches

This approaches stem from the observation that any subgraph of a frequent subgraph must be frequent as well.

FSG is one of the first methods that utilizes the apriori principle. The algorithm builds on the idea that a frequent kkk-subgraph is built on top of frequent (k−1)(k-1)(k−1)-subgraphs, where kkk indicates the number of edges.

The algorithm simply starts enumerating frequent 111-subgraphs and 222-subgraphs and store them into the set F1,F2F_1,F_2F1​,F2​ respectively.

Similarly, FkF_kFk​ is the set of frequent kkk-subgraphs. FSG then builds larger kkk-subgraphs by merging the subgraphs obtained in the previous iteration.

Pseudo code

  1. F1←F_1\getsF1​← frequent 111-subgraphs with counts
  2. F2←F_2\getsF2​← frequent 222-subgraphs with counts
  3. k←3k\gets3k←3
  4. while Fk−1≠∅F_{k-1}\neq\emptyFk−1​=∅ do
    • candidate_generation: get CkC_kCk​, the set of candidate kkk-subgraphs from Fk−1F_{k-1}Fk−1​
    • candidate_pruning: for a candidate to be frequent, each (k−1)(k-1)(k−1)-subgraph should be frequent
    • frequency_pruning: scan D\mathcal DD, count occurrences of subgraphs in CkC_kCk​
    • Fk←{c∈Ck∣σ(c)≥min⁡sup⁡}F_k\gets\{c\in C_k|\sigma(c)\ge\min\sup\}Fk​←{c∈Ck​∣σ(c)≥minsup}
    • k←k+1k\gets k+1k←k+1
  5. return ∪i=1kFi\cup_{i=1}^kF_i∪i=1k​Fi​

each of 3 steps run isomorphism checks to understand whether some candidate is isomorphic to any of the other candidates. Moreover, in order to compute the support of a subgraph the algorithm runs subgraph isomorphism on all the candidate graphs in CkC_kCk​. FSG employs heuristics to reduce the number of isomorphism tests at each iteration.

Candidate Generation

Generate candidates by merging the frequent (k−1)(k-1)(k−1)-subgraphs. The main idea is to first detect cores to generate the candidates easily. A core is the maximum common subgraph among two subgraphs. Although generating the core requires to run subgraph isomorphism, in practice

  1. one core is common to many subgraphs.
  2. the subgraphs are typically small.

Candidate pruning

In order to prune the candidates we can check if every subgraph of a candidate is also frequent. In theory, this requires to perform isomorphism tests for each of the candidate’s subgraph.

In order to hash a graph, we require a signature, i.e., a numeric representation, that is unique for each graph. This is possible through canonical labeling. Canonical labeling, finds a unique representation of a graph in a smart manner. In particular, FSG empolys a canonical scheme that reorders the column and the rows of the adjacency matrix. The string obtained by reading the sequence of node and edge labels in the column of the matrix that is smallest lexicographic string among all of those obtained by reordering is the canonical code and is unique, i.e., code(G)=min⁡code(M)∣Mcode(G)=\min code(M)|Mcode(G)=mincode(M)∣M is adjacency matrix.

It seems that this method effectively solves graph isomorphism in O(1)\mathcal O(1)O(1). However, this is not the case as the canonical labeling is obtained by a, potentially exponential, number of reordering of the adjacency matrix. By reordering, we are computing automorphisms over the graph. In practice, not all the permutations lead to a valid matrix and can be pruned by simple heuristics.

Frequency Counting

Frequency counting requires to scan the data to find which graphs contain a subgraph. In frequency counting, most of the subgraph isomorphism tests can be avoided with a simple shortcut.

Let TID(G′),TID(G′′)TID(G'),TID(G'')TID(G′),TID(G′′) be the set of graphs in the collection D\mathcal DD that contain the subgraph G′G'G′ and G′′G''G′′, respectively. If we merge the two patterns, it follows immediately that TID(merge(G′,G′′))⊆TID(G′)∩TID(G′′)TID(merge(G',G''))\subseteq TID(G')\cap TID(G'')TID(merge(G′,G′′))⊆TID(G′)∩TID(G′′). As such all the graphs in (TID(G′)∪TID(G′′))╲(TID(G′)∩TID(G′′))(TID(G')\cup TID(G''))\diagdown(TID(G')\cap TID(G''))(TID(G′)∪TID(G′′))╲(TID(G′)∩TID(G′′)) can be ignored as they will not contribute to the support.

👍

  • Finds all frequent subgraphs.
  • Easy to include heuristics to reduce the computation time.

👎

  • FSG generates the same subgraph a large number of times.
  • The canonical labeling scheme is quadratic in the size of the subgraph.
  • FSG requires several isomorphism and subgraph isomorphism tests.

Pattern-growth Approaches

It follows a different philosophy.

Start first with empty subgraphs and progressively expand these subgraphs by adding one edge at the time. The pattern expands always in a certain order to redundancy as much as possible.

gSpan is the most famous algorithm in the pattern-growth family.

gSpan organizes the patterns in a prefix-tree, a data structure for alphabetically ordered string that store string prefixes as nodes of a tree. However, graphs do not have a predefined order of traversal, or a unique way of enumerating the nodes.

To create a prefix-tree of non-repeating patterns gSpan:

  1. Defines a traversal over the nodes in the graphs
  2. Identifies in advance which nodes of a subgraph to expand
  3. Defines a total ordering over the subgraphs, so as to detect duplicate patterns.

Node Traversal

gSpan traverses the subgraphs in a DFS manner, that means that the next node vjv_jvj​ to visit after viv_ivi​ is the first in the list of neighbors N(i)N(i)N(i). A DFS vist defines a spanning-tree over the nodes in the subgraph. The edges in the spanning tree are called forward edges; the remaining edges are called backward edges.

In the beginning of the DFS a counter assigns a unique identifier to each node. The counter represents the discovery time of the node.

Rightmost Expansion

Since a DFS defines a specific traversal and the order of the visit is market by a counter, there is only one way to add an edge to the subgraph, namely expanding from the rightmost path. The rightmost path is the path from the root of the spanning tree to the leaf with the highest identifier.

Total Ordering

The main innovation of gSpan is to treat canonical labeling as a DFS-visit and thus ensure a reduced number of operations and redundant subgraphs.

DFS Codes

Representation of a graph that is comparable among other DFS codes. Such a comparison as a total ordering for which a minimum exists. The minimum DFS-code is a canonical labeling of a graph.

Definition of DFS-edge. It’s a tuple (i,j,ℓ(i),ℓ((i,j)),ℓ(j))(i,j,\ell(i),\ell((i,j)),\ell(j))(i,j,ℓ(i),ℓ((i,j)),ℓ(j)) where i,ji,ji,j are identifiers given by the DFS traversal order, ℓ(i),ℓ((i,j)),ℓ(j)\ell(i),\ell((i,j)),\ell(j)ℓ(i),ℓ((i,j)),ℓ(j) are the labels of node iii, edge (i,j)(i,j)(i,j) and node jjj.

DFS-code for a graph G=(V,E,ℓ)G=(V,E,\ell)G=(V,E,ℓ) is a sequence ⟨e1,⋯ ,et⟩\langle e_1,\cdots,e_t\rangle⟨e1​,⋯,et​⟩ where each eie_iei​ is a DFS-edge and t=∣E∣t=|E|t=∣E∣.

Valid DFS-codes. Precedence order ≺\prec≺ on DFS-edges corresponding to the DFS traversal. Given 2 DFS-edges e1e_1e1​ connecting nodes with discovery time (i1,j1)(i_1,j_1)(i1​,j1​) and e2e_2e2​ connecting nodes with discovery time (i2,j2)(i_2,j_2)(i2​,j2​). A DFS-code is valid if it complies to:

  1. i1=i2i_1=i_2i1​=i2​ and j1<j2⇒e1≺e2j_1\lt j_2\Rarr e_1\prec e_2j1​<j2​⇒e1​≺e2​ backward edges ordering
  2. i1<j1i_1\lt j_1i1​<j1​ and j1=i2⇒e1≺e2j_1=i_2\Rarr e_1\prec e_2j1​=i2​⇒e1​≺e2​ forward edges ordering
  3. e1≺e2e_1\prec e_2e1​≺e2​ and e2≺e3⇒e1≺e3e_2\prec e_3\Rarr e_1\prec e_3e2​≺e3​⇒e1​≺e3​ transitive property

Total ordering and minimum codes. A graph can have multiple valid DFS-codes depending on the DFS traversal order. gSpan further defines a total ordering over the DFS-codes so to define a minimum DFS-code for a graph.

The minimum DFS-code is unique and a canonical labeling of the graph. This implies that 2 graphs are isomorphic iff they have the same DFS-code.

Let α,β\alpha,\betaα,β two DFS-codes. We say α≺β\alpha\prec\betaα≺β iff either of the following conditions are true:

  • ∃t,0≤t≤min⁡(n,m)\exist t,0\le t\le\min(n,m)∃t,0≤t≤min(n,m) s.t. ak=bka_k=b_kak​=bk​ for k<tk\lt tk<t and at≺ebta_t\prec_e b_tat​≺e​bt​
  • ak=bka_k=b_kak​=bk​ for 0≤k≤m0\le k\le m0≤k≤m and n≥mn\ge mn≥m

Simply speaking, α≺β\alpha\prec\betaα≺β if either 1. α\alphaα and β\betaβ are equal up to some point ttt and the next corresponding DFS-edges is s.t. at≺ebta_t\prec_e b_tat​≺e​bt​, or 2. α\alphaα and β\betaβ are the same in terms of DFS-edges but β\betaβ contains more edges.

We need to define ≺e\prec_e≺e​: Let at=(ia,ja,Lia,Lia,ja,Lja),bt=(ib,jb,Lib,Lib,jb,Ljb)a_t=(i_a,j_a,L_{i_a},L_{i_a,j_a},L_{j_a}),b_t=(i_b,j_b,L_{i_b},L_{i_b,j_b},L_{j_b})at​=(ia​,ja​,Lia​​,Lia​,ja​​,Lja​​),bt​=(ib​,jb​,Lib​​,Lib​,jb​​,Ljb​​) be two DFS-edges. We say at≺ebta_t\prec_e b_tat​≺e​bt​ if

  1. Both are forward edges
    • ib<iai_b\lt i_aib​<ia​ OR
    • ib=iai_b=i_aib​=ia​ and the labels of aaa are lexicographical less than labels of bbb, in order of tuple.
  2. Both are backward edges
    • ja≤jbj_a\le j_bja​≤jb​ OR
    • ja=jbj_a=j_bja​=jb​ and the edge label of aaa is lexicographical less than the one of bbb.
  3. ata_tat​ is backward and btb_tbt​ is forward.

The above enforce a total order on DFS-codes and, as such, the min-DFS(GGG) of a graph GGG is a canonical labeling of GGG.

DFS-code tree. It allows also to organize data into DFS-tree that is prefix tree. Because the codes have a precedence order. If min-DFS(G1G_1G1​)={a0,a1,⋯ ,an}=\{a_0,a_1,\cdots,a_n\}={a0​,a1​,⋯,an​} and min-DFS(G2G_2G2​)={a0,a1,⋯ ,an,b}=\{a_0,a_1,\cdots,a_n,b\}={a0​,a1​,⋯,an​,b}, then G1G_1G1​ is parent of G2G_2G2​, since min-DFS(G1G_1G1​) is a prefix of min-DFS(G2G_2G2​).

Given a parent-child relationship defined, we can construct a DFS Tree. An interesting property of the DFS-tree is that an in-order traveersal follows DFS lexicographic order.

gSpan algorithm

Input: Collection of graphs D\mathcal DD, minimum support min⁡sup⁡\min\supminsup

Output: Frequent subgraph set SSS

  1. Let SSS be frequent one-edge subgraphs in D\mathcal DD using DFS code.
  2. Sort SSS in lexicographic order
  3. N←SN\gets SN←S
  4. for each n∈Nn\in Nn∈N do
    • GSpanExtend(D,n,min⁡sup⁡,S)(\mathcal D,n,\min\sup,S)(D,n,minsup,S)
  5. return SSS

GSpanExtend(D,n,min⁡sup⁡,S)(\mathcal D,n,\min\sup,S)(D,n,minsup,S) // checking minimality of DFS-code is computationally expensive

  1. if nnn not minimal then return

  2. else

    • S←S∪nS\gets S\cup nS←S∪n

    • for each Rightmost expansion eee of nnn do

      • if δ(e)≥min⁡sup⁡\delta(e)\ge\min\supδ(e)≥minsup then

        GSpanExtend(D,n,min⁡sup⁡,S)(\mathcal D,n,\min\sup,S)(D,n,minsup,S)

👍

  • Finds all frequent subgraphs.
  • Generates less redundant subgraphs.

👎

  • Works only in collections of graphs.
  • Generally slow for low min⁡sup⁡\min\supminsup.

Frequent Subgraph Mining on a Single Graph

If the support is defined a the number of time a specific subgraph appears, the downward property does not hold anymore as bigger subgraphs can have a larger support.

We defined a support measure to be admissible if for any graph PPP and any subgraph Q⊑PQ\sqsubseteq PQ⊑P, the support of PPP is not larger than the support of QQQ. In the last few years, a number of admissible support measures have appeared. These include,

  • Maximum independent set support (MIS): Based on maximum number of non-overlapping matches
  • Harmful overlap support (HO): Based on number of patterns for which no multi-node subgraph is identical
  • Minimum image-based support (MNI): Based on the number of times a node in the pattern is mapped into a distinct node in the graph.

MIS Support

The maximum independent set support σMIS\sigma_{MIS}σMIS​ counts how many times a pattern maps to a subgraph that does not overlap to any other subgraphs. The computation of MIS is as follows

  1. Construct an overlap graph GO=(VO,EO)G_O=(V_O,E_O)GO​=(VO​,EO​), in which the set of nodes VOV_OVO​ is the set of matches of a pattern PPP into a graph GGG and E_O=\{(f_1,f_2)|f_1,f_2\in V_O\or f_1\neq f_2\neq f_1\sqcap f_2\neq\empty\}, i.e., EOE_OEO​ has an edge among each pair of overlapping matches.
  2. Compute the σMIS\sigma_{MIS}σMIS​ as the size of the maximum independent set of nodes in the overlap graph.

Recall that the maximum finding the maximum independent set of NP-hard.

Harmful Overlap Support

The HO support is less restrictive than MIS support as it considers overlap only those matchings of a pattern that share one are more edges. Two matching subgraph are connected through a node are not considered overlapping.

NMI Support

The minimum image-based support is even less restrictive as it considers the minimum number of times a node of the pattern matches a node in the graph.

Definition of MNI. Let f1,⋯ ,fmf_1,\cdots,f_mf1​,⋯,fm​ be the set of isomorphism of a pattern P:⟨VP,EP,ℓP⟩P:\langle V_P,E_P,\ell_P\rangleP:⟨VP​,EP​,ℓP​⟩ in a graph GGG. Let F(v)=∣{f1(v),⋯ ,fm(v)}∣F(v)=|\{f_1(v),\cdots,f_m(v)\}|F(v)=∣{f1​(v),⋯,fm​(v)}∣ be the number of distinct mappings of a node v∈VPv\in V_Pv∈VP​ to a node in GGG by functions f1,⋯ ,fmf_1,\cdots,f_mf1​,⋯,fm​. The MNI

σMNI(P) ofP in G is σMNI(P)=min⁡{F(v),v∈VP}\sigma_{MNI}(P)\ of P\ in\ G\ is\ \sigma_{MNI}(P)=\min\{F(v),v\in V_P\}σMNI​(P) ofP in G is σMNI​(P)=min{F(v),v∈VP​}

Since MNI considers one node at the time, given the matching of pattern in the graph, NMI support can be computed in polynomial time.

Approaches for Large Graphs

With an anti-monotone support measure, we can apply any previous support measure such as gSPAN, just changing how the support is computed and leaving the rest unchanged. Such approaches are called grow-and-store

  • Add all frequent edges to the list of frequent subgraphs
  • Extend frequent subgraphs to larger candidates
  • Compute candidate frequency (find all occurrences)
  • Repeat step 2 until no more frequent subgraphs is found

One of the methods that exploits and optimizes gSpan is GraMi
entry.summary: A labeled graph is a triple

entry.title: 随机算法 10 Invertible Bloom Filters
entry.content:
Brief Introduction

Invertible Bloom Lookup Table (abbr. IBLT)

a fancy hash-table stores key-value pair (x,y)(x,y)(x,y)

space budget: ttt

Guarantee

It “works” when the number of key-value pairs, nnn, in table has n≤tn\le tn≤t.

“temporarily” stops working if n>tn\gt tn>t.

starts working again if nnn drops below ttt.

Operations

(x,y) is key-value pair.

insert(x,y), delete(x,y), get(x), listentries.

Details

Start with table with k≥3k\ge3k≥3 rows, m=2×tm=2\times tm=2×t columns.

In each row, we have a hash function h1,⋯ ,hkh_1,\cdots,h_kh1​,⋯,hk​.

hih_ihi​ is universal.

Each of the entry, called cell, stores values:

  • count
  • key_sum
  • value_sum

Insert Operation

  1. for i=1i=1i=1 to kkk
    • c=A[i][hi(x)]c=A[i][h_i(x)]c=A[i][hi​(x)]
    • c.count++c.count++c.count++
    • c.key_sum+=xc.key\_sum+= xc.key_sum+=x
    • c.value_sum+=yc.value\_sum+=yc.value_sum+=y

Delete Operation

“undo” insert operation

We must know the pair is there before deletion.

  1. for i=1i=1i=1 to kkk
    • c=A[i][hi(x)]c=A[i][h_i(x)]c=A[i][hi​(x)]
    • c.count−−c.count--c.count−−
    • c.key_sum−=xc.key\_sum-= xc.key_sum−=x
    • c.value_sum−=yc.value\_sum-=yc.value_sum−=y

Get Operation

slightly different from min sketch count

  1. ret=∞ret=\inftyret=∞

  2. for i=1i=1i=1 to kkk

    • c=A[i][hi(x)]c=A[i][h_i(x)]c=A[i][hi​(x)]

    • if c.count==0c.count==0c.count==0 return “not there”

    • else if c.count==1c.count==1c.count==1 then

      • if c.key_sum==xc.key\_sum==xc.key_sum==x

        return c.value_sumc.value\_sumc.value_sum

      • else return “not there”

  3. return “don’t know”

Probability of Success

If n≤tn\le tn≤t, then get(x) succeeds with probability ≥1−2−k\ge1-2^{-k}≥1−2−k.

Assume k>1k\gt1k>1, nnn pairs: (xi,yi)(x_i,y_i)(xi​,yi​) is stored in IBLT, n≤tn\le tn≤t.

For get(x)

  • If xxx is in IBLT

    1. 当 xxx 在 IBLT 的这一行里面，但是 get 函数发现对应的哈希值指向的位置都发生了碰撞的概率。
    2. 明明 xxx 不在 IBLT 中，但是 get 函数发现对应的哈希值指向的位置中存在一个值，即 count=1 但 value 不是 xxx 对应的。

    Define fail-event Ei:{h(x)=h(xi)}E_i:\{h(x)=h(x_i)\}Ei​:{h(x)=h(xi​)},

Pr⁡[get(x) fails]=Pr⁡[⋃xi≠xEi]≤∑xi≠xPr⁡[Ei]≤∑xi≠x1m=n−1m≤t−1m=t−12t≤12\Pr[get(x)\text{ fails}]=\Pr[\bigcup_{x_i\neq x}E_i]\le\sum_{x_i\neq x}\Pr[E_i]\\\le\sum_{x_i\neq x}\frac{1}{m}=\frac{n-1}{m}\le\frac{t-1}{m}=\frac{t-1}{2t}\le\frac{1}{2}Pr[get(x) fails]=Pr[xi​=x⋃​Ei​]≤xi​=x∑​Pr[Ei​]≤xi​=x∑​m1​=mn−1​≤mt−1​=2tt−1​≤21​

  • If xxx is not in IBLT.

    明明 xxx 不在 IBLT 的这一行里面，但是 get 函数得出该键对应的哈希值指向的位置在 IBLT 这一行中产生碰撞的概率。

    Define fail-event Eij={h(x)=h(xi)=h(xj)}E_{ij}=\{h(x)=h(x_i)=h(x_j)\}Eij​={h(x)=h(xi​)=h(xj​)}

    Pr⁡[⋃i≠jEij]≤∑i<jPr⁡[Eij]=∑i<j1m2=Cn21m2=n(n−1)2m2≤t22m2≤t28t2=18\Pr[\bigcup_{i\neq j}E_{ij}]\le\sum_{i\lt j}\Pr[E_{ij}]=\sum_{i\lt j}\frac{1}{m^2}=C_n^2\frac{1}{m^2}\\=\frac{n(n-1)}{2m^2}\le\frac{t^2}{2m^2}\le\frac{t^2}{8t^2}=\frac{1}{8}Pr[i=j⋃​Eij​]≤i<j∑​Pr[Eij​]=i<j∑​m21​=Cn2​m21​=2m2n(n−1)​≤2m2t2​≤8t2t2​=81​

If we choose k=log⁡2t+log⁡21δk=\log_2t+\log_2\frac{1}{\delta}k=log2​t+log2​δ1​, the probability of failure is at most δ\deltaδ.

How to Avoid False Deletion?

another set of universal hash function g1,⋯ ,gk:U→[R]g_1,\cdots,g_k:U\rarr[R]g1​,⋯,gk​:U→[R]

while query, check whether c.hash_sum==g(c.key_sum)c.hash\_sum==g(c.key\_sum)c.hash_sum==g(c.key_sum)

ListEntries Operation

  1. Q=∅Q=\emptyQ=∅

  2. for ccc in IBLT

    • if c.count==1c.count==1c.count==1
      • Q.push(c.key_sum,c.value_sum)Q.push(c.key\_sum,c.value\_sum)Q.push(c.key_sum,c.value_sum)

    // Max size of QQQ is mkmkmk here

    • while Q.size>0Q.size\gt0Q.size>0

      • (x,y)=Q.top()(x,y)=Q.top()(x,y)=Q.top()

      • Q.pop()Q.pop()Q.pop()

      • if output.continas(x)==falseoutput.continas(x)==falseoutput.continas(x)==false

        output.add(x,y)output.add(x,y)output.add(x,y)

      • for i=1i=1i=1 to kkk

        • c′=A[i][hi(x)]c'=A[i][h_i(x)]c′=A[i][hi​(x)]
        • c′.count−−c'.count--c′.count−−
        • c′.key_sum−=xc'.key\_sum-=xc′.key_sum−=x
        • c′.value_sum−=yc'.value\_sum-=yc′.value_sum−=y
        • if c′.count==1c'.count==1c′.count==1
          • Q.push(c′.key_sum,c′,value_sum)Q.push(c'.key\_sum,c',value\_sum)Q.push(c′.key_sum,c′,value_sum)

Analysis of Success Probability

hyper-graph

node: memory location

hhh is truly random

nnn edges, e1,⋯ ,ene_1,\cdots,e_ne1​,⋯,en​ are independently uniformly random.

List entries fails iff non-empty 2-core exists.

i.e. largest subgraph where every node has degree≥2degree\ge2degree≥2

F={ListEntries fails}F=\{ListEntries\text{ fails}\}F={ListEntries fails}

Fj={ListEntries fails with j key-value left}F_j=\{ListEntries\text{ fails with j key-value left}\}Fj​={ListEntries fails with j key-value left}

Pr⁡[F]=Pr⁡[⋃j=2nFj]≤∑j=2nPr⁡[Fj]   (1)\Pr[F]=\Pr[\bigcup_{j=2}^nF_j]\le\sum_{j=2}^n\Pr[F_j]\ \ \ (1)Pr[F]=Pr[j=2⋃n​Fj​]≤j=2∑n​Pr[Fj​]   (1)

For every S∈CxjS\in C_{x}^jS∈Cxj​, FjS={ListEntries fails, with S as j keys}F_{jS}=\{ListEntries\text{ fails, with S as j keys}\}FjS​={ListEntries fails, with S as j keys}

(1)=∑j=2nPr⁡[⋃S∈CxjFjS]≤∑j=2n∑S∈CxjPr⁡[FjS]   (2)(1)=\sum_{j=2}^n\Pr[\bigcup_{S\in C_x^j}F_{jS}]\le\sum_{j=2}^n\sum_{S\in C_x^j}\Pr[F_{jS}]\ \ \ (2)(1)=j=2∑n​Pr[S∈Cxj​⋃​FjS​]≤j=2∑n​S∈Cxj​∑​Pr[FjS​]   (2)

Denote: (T1,⋯ ,Tk)∈(C[m]j/2)k(T_1,\cdots,T_k)\in (C_{[m]}^{j/2})^k(T1​,⋯,Tk​)∈(C[m]j/2​)k

Fj,S,T1,⋯ ,Tk={LE fails for S and ∀i:hi(S)⊆Ti}F_{j,S,T_1,\cdots,T_k}=\{LE\text{ fails for S and }\forall_i:h_i(S)\subseteq T_i\}Fj,S,T1​,⋯,Tk​​={LE fails for S and ∀i​:hi​(S)⊆Ti​}

(2)=∑j=2n∑S∈Cxj∑(T1,⋯ ,Tk)∈(C[m]j/2)kPr⁡[Fj,S,T1,⋯ ,Tk]   (3)(2)=\sum_{j=2}^n\sum_{S\in C_x^j}\sum_{(T_1,\cdots,T_k)\in (C_{[m]}^{j/2})^k}\Pr[F_{j,S,T_1,\cdots,T_k}]\ \ \ (3)(2)=j=2∑n​S∈Cxj​∑​(T1​,⋯,Tk​)∈(C[m]j/2​)k∑​Pr[Fj,S,T1​,⋯,Tk​​]   (3)

Pr⁡[h1(x1)⊆T1]=j2mPr⁡[h1(S)⊆T1=(j2m)jPr⁡[∀i:hi(S)⊆Ti]=(j2m)jkPr⁡[Fj,S,T1,⋯ ,Tk]≤Pr⁡[∀i:hi(S)⊆Ti]=(j2m)jk(3)≤∑j=2nCnj(Cmj/2)k(j2m)jk≤∑j=2n(enj)j(m2ej)jk/2(j2m)jk=∑j=2n(enj)j(jem2)jk/2=∑j=2n(e2n2m)j(je2m)j(k/2−1)≤∑j=2n2−j(je2m)j(k/2−1)≤2⋅14⋅(em)k−2≤(em)k−2≤(1/t)k−2\Pr[h_1(x_1)\subseteq T_1]=\frac{j}{2m}\\\Pr[h_1(S)\subseteq T_1=(\frac{j}{2m})^j\\\Pr[\forall_i:h_i(S)\subseteq T_i]=(\frac{j}{2m})^{jk}\\\Pr[F_{j,S,T_1,\cdots,T_k}]\le\Pr[\forall_i:h_i(S)\subseteq T_i]=(\frac{j}{2m})^{jk}\\(3)\le\sum_{j=2}^n C_n^j (C_m^{j/2})^k(\frac{j}{2m})^{jk}\le\sum_{j=2}^n(\frac{en}{j})^j(\frac{m2e}{j})^{jk/2}(\frac{j}{2m})^{jk}\\=\sum_{j=2}^n(\frac{en}{j})^j(\frac{je}{m2})^{jk/2}=\sum_{j=2}^n(\frac{e^2n}{2m})^j(\frac{je}{2m})^{j(k/2-1)}\\\le\sum_{j=2}^n2^{-j}(\frac{je}{2m})^{j(k/2-1)}\le2\cdot\frac{1}{4}\cdot(\frac{e}{m})^{k-2}\le(\frac{e}{m})^{k-2}\le(1/t)^{k-2}Pr[h1​(x1​)⊆T1​]=2mj​Pr[h1​(S)⊆T1​=(2mj​)jPr[∀i​:hi​(S)⊆Ti​]=(2mj​)jkPr[Fj,S,T1​,⋯,Tk​​]≤Pr[∀i​:hi​(S)⊆Ti​]=(2mj​)jk(3)≤j=2∑n​Cnj​(Cmj/2​)k(2mj​)jk≤j=2∑n​(jen​)j(jm2e​)jk/2(2mj​)jk=j=2∑n​(jen​)j(m2je​)jk/2=j=2∑n​(2me2n​)j(2mje​)j(k/2−1)≤j=2∑n​2−j(2mje​)j(k/2−1)≤2⋅41​⋅(me​)k−2≤(me​)k−2≤(1/t)k−2

entry.title: 丹麦 IT 学生工求职记
entry.content:
Kdag (Katrinebjerg Karrieredag) 2024

2024 年 4 月 12 日，期待已久的 Kdag 😍

在 Katrinebjerg AUDatalogi 的 Nygaard 楼，一年一度🎆

总共有 54 家企业/单位，针对 IT 的岗位信息交流会。我认得的企业也就 乐高、Arla（乳制品垄断企业，经常喝这家的牛奶）、Uber。

也有跟国防有关的企业，看宣传资料像是给 F35 战机生产零部件的企业，反正 in collaboration with Lockheed Martin （一眼不招非 EU 国籍的）

有些企业是针对丹麦本地的生意，或者员工大部分是丹麦人的。这种企业的宣传资料上只有丹麦语的，也可以直接跳过了。所以想在丹麦有更多的工作机会，需要学好丹麦语😭

还有就是，说 danish is not mandatory, but highly recommended 的，那就是 mandatory 的意思。

为什么我喜欢这样的活动

可以白嫖吃的喝的，谁不喜欢啊？😍😍😍

目标

主要是有 Student Job 岗位的企业，狠狠地投简历！

有些企业没有 Student Job 岗位，但是有 Graduate Program，相当于轮岗实习一段时间，看表现再转正。这种公司我现在就不能申请。

如果万一由公司要我了，俺就立马就辞去餐厅端盘子的活儿。

岗位偏好

没有特殊偏好，我认为我自己“可塑性”还是有的。

可以前后端 也可以算法 还可以数据科学的岗位（虽然这些都不会，但是可以学）

一些感兴趣的企业

LEGO

岗位数极少，说是先从海量简历中选 100 个人左右去企业参加一个类似于试用选拔的项目，一年左右再淘汰（听起来感觉有点卷？）。IT 方向在丹麦的岗位 2024 年也就二三十个 hc。

Student Job 岗位于 4 月 15 日放出。只有 27 个名额。

要求一周至少一天现场办公（比隆/哥本哈根）

太知名了，很多人都想去。申着玩，估计没戏。我也好想去，毕竟乐高是我童年为数不多的美好回忆😭

Uber

Uber 的确在招人，奥胡斯岗位数：2。😓一个全职岗位，一个兼职岗位……💦

名声在外的打车软件公司，薪水应该很好吧。

Danish Crown

一家食品公司，好像是干猪牛肉制品生产的企业。

其中有个 Student workers for Data Science Team 的岗位我挺感兴趣的。

主要是提供计算机视觉等 AI 算法针对生产工程的解决方案，一些项目比如：

  • Commodity and livestock forecasting
  • Object detection to automate reading and tracking of hides
  • Applying MLOps to new and existing products in the cloud
  • Discovering existing data sources that can be used to generate potential new products

因为之前在华为搞过一点 CV，可能算是对这个岗位有一丢丢经验吧。

工作地点在 Randers，奥胡斯北边的一座城市，坐公交大概四十分钟的样子。

期望工作时间：10 - 15 小时/周

时薪：145 丹麦克朗

🎯投起来！

Nitor Energy

一家能源交易公司，官网地址。

有招 Student Software Developer

Python, Typescript(REACT), C#, Microsoft SQL, Microsoft Azure

工作地点位于奥胡斯市中心

在官网投递简历

🎯投起来！

Better Collection

电子竞技相关，官网地址

旗下包含 HLTV.org 反恐精英相关, FUTBIN.com 实况足球集卡网站 等

支持兼职 Student Job，并且办公地点就在奥胡斯大学计算机学院那一片。

Kotlin （没听说过，不会，但是可以学）React

在官网投递简历

🎯投起来！

总之就是，氛围很好，人很多。

Endeavour

Danish Crown

数据科学小组 - 学生工岗位

2024 年 4 月 13 日通过邮件投递 Cover Letter + CV + 成绩单

2024 年 4 月 15 日收到团队领导的回复，预计 2024 年 4 月 17 日面试。

2024 年 4 月 7 日上午远程面试。小组组长和一个同事面我。我先自我介绍一下，然后他们问我一些问题。主要是很 general 的问题，没有涉及到什么专业和技术细节。但是我撇脚的英语口语让我觉得很尴尬。允许 work-from-home，但是最好偶尔去现场办公。

面试结果可能周五或下周一通过邮件/电话。

Better Collection

Software Developer in Esports - HLTV/Counterstrike

2024 年 4 月 13 日通过官网投递 Cover Letter + CV

Nitor Energy

Student Software Developer

2024 年 4 月 13 日通过官网投递 Cover Letter + CV + 成绩单

Danske Commodities

也是一家能源交易公司

Student Software Developer

2024 年 4 月 14 日通过官网投递 Cover Letter + CV + 成绩单

LEGO™

2024 年 4 月 16 日通过官网投递 CV

投递岗位：Digital Technology Early Career Student Worker

方向选择：1. Software Engineering; 2. Data & AI

2024 年 4 月 17 日简历挂😭

entry.title: 数据挖掘 10 Graph Neural Networks
entry.content:
GNN - graph neural networks

Intuition: how to propagate information over the neighbors in a non-linear manner.

Graph Embeddings as Matrix Factorization

Linear embeddings correspond to SVD of the similarity matrices chosen in the objective.

For adjacency-based similarity, the best linear ddd-dimensional embedding corresponds to the projection of the dataset into the ddd directions associated to the top-ddd singular values:

if SVD(A)=UΣV⊤then the embedding matrix Z=UdΣd\text{if }SVD(\mathbf A)=\mathbf U\Sigma\mathbf V^\top\\\text{then the embedding matrix }\mathbf Z=\mathbf U_d\Sigma_dif SVD(A)=UΣV⊤then the embedding matrix Z=Ud​Σd​

Question: Does there exist a matrix that, once factorized, would be approximately equivalent to run gradient descent over the non-linear objective?

NetMF

DeepWalk, one of the most popular random-walk embedding methods.

A random-walk approach samples random walks using a certain strategy RRR.

A random-walk embedding method optimizes the likelihood that a node jjj is reachable from a random-walk starting from node iii.

DeepWalk’s strategy is to generate random-walks of length LLL and then generate pairs of co-occuring nodes in a window of size TTT. The co-occurences are stored in a multiset D\mathcal DD.

Pseudo-code:

  • for each n=1,2,⋯ ,Nn=1,2,\cdots,Nn=1,2,⋯,N do
    • pick w1nw_1^nw1n​ according to probability distribution p(w1)p(w_1)p(w1​)
    • generate vertex sequence (w1n,⋯ ,wLn)(w_1^n,\cdots,w_L^n)(w1n​,⋯,wLn​) of length LLL by random walk on network GGG
    • for each j=1,2,⋯ ,L−Tj=1,2,\cdots,L-Tj=1,2,⋯,L−T do
      • for each r=1,⋯ ,Tr=1,\cdots,Tr=1,⋯,T do
        • add vertex-context pair (wjn,wj+rn)(w_j^n,w_{j+r}^n)(wjn​,wj+rn​) to multi-set D\mathcal DD
        • add vertex-context pair (wj+rn,wjn)(w_{j+r}^n,w_{j}^n)(wj+rn​,wjn​) to multi-set D\mathcal DD

The first vertex of the random-walk w1nw_1^nw1n​ is sampled from a prior distribution p(w1)p(w_1)p(w1​) that in undirected, connected bipartite graphs correspond to p(i)=di/2∣E∣p(i)=d_i/2|E|p(i)=di​/2∣E∣.

This process and the relative transformation through softmax corresponds to a similarity matrix. We can represent the similarity among two nodes i,ji,ji,j as

\log\left(\frac{\text{(# of RW between i and j)}\cdot\text{(# of node/context pairs)}}{k\text{(# of occurrences of i)}\cdot\text{(# of occurrences of j)}}\right)\\=\log\left(\frac{\#(i,j)|\mathcal D|}{k\#(i)\#(j)}\right)

where kkk is the number of negative samples.

Understand this formula:

  • First partition the set of multi-set D\mathcal DD of pairs of nodes co-occurring in walks into two set Dr→\mathcal D_{r\rarr}Dr→​ and Dr←\mathcal D_{r\larr}Dr←​

    Dr→={(w,c):(w,c)∈D,w=wjn,c=wj+rn}Dr←={(w,c):(w,c)∈D,c=wj+rn,w=wjn}\mathcal D_{r\rarr}=\{(w,c):(w,c)\in\mathcal D,w=w_j^n,c=w_{j+r}^n\}\\\mathcal D_{r\larr}=\{(w,c):(w,c)\in\mathcal D,c=w_{j+r}^n,w=w_j^n\}Dr→​={(w,c):(w,c)∈D,w=wjn​,c=wj+rn​}Dr←​={(w,c):(w,c)∈D,c=wj+rn​,w=wjn​}

  • Then observe that

    log⁡(#(i,j)∣D∣k#(i)#(j))=log⁡(#(i,j)÷∣D∣k(#(i)÷∣D∣)(#(j)÷∣D∣))#(i,j)÷∣D∣=12T∑r=1T(#(i,j)r→∣D∣r→+#(i,j)r←∣D∣r←)\log\left(\frac{\#(i,j)|\mathcal D|}{k\#(i)\#(j)}\right)=\log\left(\frac{\#(i,j)\div|\mathcal D|}{k(\#(i)\div|\mathcal D|)(\#(j)\div|\mathcal D|)}\right)\\\#(i,j)\div|\mathcal D|=\frac{1}{2T}\sum_{r=1}^T\left(\frac{\#(i,j)_{r\rarr}}{|\mathcal D|_{r\rarr}}+\frac{\#(i,j)_{r\larr}}{|\mathcal D|_{r\larr}}\right)log(k#(i)#(j)#(i,j)∣D∣​)=log(k(#(i)÷∣D∣)(#(j)÷∣D∣)#(i,j)÷∣D∣​)#(i,j)÷∣D∣=2T1​r=1∑T​(∣D∣r→​#(i,j)r→​​+∣D∣r←​#(i,j)r←​​)

    where the latter observation comes from ∣Dr→∣/∣D∣=∣Dr←∣/∣D∣=12T|\mathcal D_{r\rarr}|/|\mathcal D|=|\mathcal D_{r\larr}|/|\mathcal D|=\frac{1}{2T}∣Dr→​∣/∣D∣=∣Dr←​∣/∣D∣=2T1​.

  • The observe what happens as the length of random walk L→∞L\rarr\infty%L→∞. We first define the random walk matrix P=Δ−1A\mathbf P=\mathbf\Delta^{-1}\mathbf AP=Δ−1A. The volume of a graph GGG is the sum of the entries of adjacency matrix vol(G)=∑i∑jai,j\text{vol}(G)=\sum_i\sum_ja_{i,j}vol(G)=∑i​∑j​ai,j​. There are 3 important Lemmas:

    \frac{\#(i,j)_{r\rarr}}{|\mathcal D|_{r\rarr}}\stackrel{p}\rarr\frac{d_i}{\text{vol(G)}}(\mathbf P^r)_{i,j}\and \frac{\#(i,j)_{r\larr}}{|\mathcal D|_{r\larr}}\stackrel{p}\rarr\frac{d_i}{\text{vol(G)}}(\mathbf P^r)_{j,i}\\\frac{\#(i,j)}{|\mathcal D|}\stackrel{p}\rarr\frac{1}{2T}\sum_{r=1}^T\left(\frac{d_i}{\text{vol(G)}}(\mathbf P^r)_{i,j}+\frac{d_i}{\text{vol(G)}}(\mathbf P^r)_{j,i}\right)\\\frac{\#(i,j)|D|}{\#(w),\#(c)}\stackrel{p}\rarr\frac{\text{vol}(G)}{2T}\left(\frac{1}{d_j}\sum_{r=1}^T(\mathbf P^r)_{i,j}+\frac{1}{d_i}\sum_{r=1}^T(\mathbf P^r)_{j,i}\right)

  • Putting all together we obtain DeepWalk with infinite length random walks converges to

    log⁡(vol(G)k(1T∑r=1T(Δ−1A)r)Δ−1)\log\left(\frac{\text{vol}(G)}{k}(\frac{1}{T}\sum_{r=1}^T(\mathbf\Delta^{-1}\mathbf A)^r)\mathbf\Delta^{-1}\right)log(kvol(G)​(T1​r=1∑T​(Δ−1A)r)Δ−1)

    Notice that the internal sum reminds close to a random walk iteration as the power of matrix Δ−1A\mathbf \Delta^{-1}\mathbf AΔ−1A encodes the probability of reaching nodes in rrr steps through random walking the graph. By factorizing such a similarity with SVD we can obtain the desired result that approximates the embeddings of a random-walk approach.

Graph Neural Network

abbr GNN

An architecture that allows nodes to propagate information to the neighbors in a non-linear manner. We have an attributed graph G=(V,E,X)G=(V,E,\mathbf X)G=(V,E,X) with matrix of node features X∈Rm×n\mathbf X\in\mathbb R^{m\times n}X∈Rm×n. (such a matrix encodes nodes attributes such as labels, profiles or characteristics)

The main ingredient of a GNN is the aggregation function that takes in input the features from the neighbors of a node iii and finds an embedding hi\mathbf h_ihi​.

Neighborhood Aggregation

Main idea: Generate node embeddings based on local neighborhoods of each node, using neural networks to represent the complex relationships of a graph.

Intuitively, think of the neighbors as a computational graph of a Neural Network.

The embeddings in the layer lll is an aggregation of the embeddings in layer l−1l-1l−1.

How to aggregate information across the layers? A simple approach: average neighbor information and apply a neural network.

The embeddings of the initial layer 000 are the attributes zi0=zi\mathbf z_i^0=\mathbf z_izi0​=zi​. The lll-th layer embedding of iii is

zil=σ(Wl∑j∈N(i)zjl−1∣N(i)∣+Blzil−1),∀t>0\mathbf z_i^l=\sigma(\mathbf W_l\sum_{j\in N(i)}\frac{\mathbf z_j^{l-1}}{|N(i)|}+\mathbf B_l\mathbf z_i^{l-1}),\forall t\gt0zil​=σ(Wl​j∈N(i)∑​∣N(i)∣zjl−1​​+Bl​zil−1​),∀t>0

σ\sigmaσ is non-linear activation function. The sum is the average of each neighbor’s embeddings compute in layer l−1l-1l−1.

Loss function. W,B\mathbf {W,B}W,B are the trainable weight matrices. After kkk-layers of neighborhood aggregation, we get output embeddings for each node. Loss function needs non-linear and differentiable.

We optimize the parameters of model through stochastic gradient descent SGD.

Rewrite model in matrix notation

Zl+1=σ(ZlWl+A~ZlW1l)\mathbf Z^{l+1}=\sigma(\mathbf Z^l\mathbf W^l+\tilde{\mathbf A}\mathbf Z^l\mathbf W^l_1)Zl+1=σ(ZlWl+A~ZlW1l​)

where A~=Δ−1/2AΔ−1/2\tilde{\mathbf A}=\mathbf\Delta^{-1/2}\mathbf {A\Delta}^{-1/2}A~=Δ−1/2AΔ−1/2. To optimize the parameters, a cross-entropy loss function would work in a supervised setting w.r.t. node’s labels.

An important properties of models: ability to share the parameters W,B\mathbf {W,B}W,B and allow for generalization to unseen nodes, edges or graphs.

Depend on loss function and embedding matrix, the GNN can learn node embeddings, graph embeddings or clusters.

Graph Convolutional Networks

abbr. GCN

A different neighbor aggragation

zil=σ(Wl∑j∈N(i)∪izjl−1∣N(i)∣∣N(j)∣).\mathbf z_i^l=\sigma\left(\mathbf W_l\sum_{j\in N(i)\cup i}\frac{\mathbf z_j^{l-1}}{\sqrt{|N(i)||N(j)|}}\right).zil​=σ⎝⎛​Wl​j∈N(i)∪i∑​∣N(i)∣∣N(j)∣​zjl−1​​⎠⎞​.

The main idea is node with a large number of connections should be less important. There is no need for the bias term B\mathbf BB and the per-neighbor normalization.

Normalization empirically attains better results and better parameter sharing. We can efficiently compute the embeddings using sparse batch operations

Zl+1=σ(Δ−1/2A~Δ−1/2ZlWl)\mathbf Z^{l+1}=\sigma(\mathbf\Delta^{-1/2}\tilde{\mathbf A}\mathbf\Delta^{-1/2}\mathbf Z^l\mathbf W_l)Zl+1=σ(Δ−1/2A~Δ−1/2ZlWl​)

where A~=A+I\tilde{\mathbf A}=\mathbf A+\mathbf IA~=A+I and δ\deltaδ is the diagonal degree matrix. The time complexity to propagate the information is O(∣E∣)\mathcal O(|E|)O(∣E∣).

GraphSAGE

Instead of fixed aggregation, GraphSAGE use any differentiable function that maps set of vectors to a single vector. So, if we use a generalized aggregation, we get

zil=σ([Wl⋅AGG({zjl−1,∀j∈N(i)}),Blzil−1])\mathbf z_i^l=\sigma([\mathbf W_l\cdot AGG(\{\mathbf z_j^{l-1},\forall j\in N(i)\}),\mathbf B_l\mathbf z_i^{l-1}])zil​=σ([Wl​⋅AGG({zjl−1​,∀j∈N(i)}),Bl​zil−1​])

Concentrate self embedding of neighbor embedding. Also we use a generalized aggregation.

Some variants:

  • Mean. Take weighted average of neighbors:

    AGG=∑j∈N(i)zjl−1N(i)AGG=\sum_{j\in N(i)}\frac{\mathbf z_j^{l-1}}{N(i)}AGG=j∈N(i)∑​N(i)zjl−1​​

  • Pool. Transform neighbor vectors and apply symmetric vector function:

    AGG=γ({Qzjl−1,∀j∈N(i)})AGG=\gamma(\{\mathbf{Qz}_j^{l-1},\forall j\in N(i)\})AGG=γ({Qzjl−1​,∀j∈N(i)})

    where we take element-wise mean/max

  • LSTM. Apply LSTM to reshuffled neighbors π(N(i))\pi(N(i))π(N(i))

    AGG=LSTM([zjl−1,∀j∈π(N(i))])AGG=LSTM([\mathbf z_j^{l-1},\forall j\in\pi(N(i))])AGG=LSTM([zjl−1​,∀j∈π(N(i))])
