entry.title: 数据挖掘 7 Community Detection
entry.content:
Community detection finds sets of nodes, i.e., that are highly connected inside the community and coarsely connected outside the community.

Community: a group of individuals sharing common interests.

A community is a subset C⊆VC\subseteq VC⊆V of the nodes VVV. Non-overlapping communities or partitions are pairwise disjoint set Ci,CjC_i,C_jCi​,Cj​ s.t. Ci∩Cj=∅C_i\cap C_j=\emptyCi​∩Cj​=∅ for each i,ji,ji,j. Overlapping communities are not necessarily pairwise disjoint.

Non-overlapping Community Detection

Disjoint aka partitions.

Two common algorithms for non-overlapping community detection are Spectral clustering and Modularity optimization.

Modularity Optimization

Modularity is a measure of cohesiveness 凝聚力 among communities.

Modularity Q\mathcal QQ compares the density inside communities with a null model of density. The null model assumes that nodes can form random connections with any other node.

Q∝∑C∈C\mathcal Q\varpropto\sum_{C\in\mathcal C}Q∝∑C∈C​ [number of edges within community CCC - expected number of edges within community CCC]

The main question is how do we quantify the edges within a community and what is a good null model.

Edge within community. In order to find how many edges belong to the same community we simply sum the edges in each community and normalize by the total number of edges.

12m∑C∈C∑i∈C∑j∈Caij\frac{1}{2m}\sum_{C\in\mathcal C}\sum_{i\in C}\sum_{j\in C}a_{ij}2m1​C∈C∑​i∈C∑​j∈C∑​aij​

We consider all pairs of nodes, we need to normalize by twice number of edges 2m2m2m as we count both ijijij and jijiji.

Modularity’s null model. Given a graph GGG with n=∣V∣n=|V|n=∣V∣ vertices and m=∣E∣m=|E|m=∣E∣ edges, construct a rewired graph G′G'G′. The rewired graph has the same degree distribution but the connections among nodes appear at random. By ensuring the same degree, we assert that we do not compare the graph GGG with a completely random one.

Node with large degrees represents celebrities. Altering their degrees might end up transforming a star into a ordinary person.

If nodes are allowed to form any connection with any other node as long as the degree is preserved, the probability that given one node iii the other one jjj is

pij=didj4m2p_{ij}=\frac{d_id_j}{4m^2}pij​=4m2di​dj​​

where di,djd_i,d_jdi​,dj​ are the degrees of iii and jjj respectively. The expected number of edges between nodes iii and jjj is 2m⋅pij=2mpij=didj2m2m\cdot p_{ij}=2mp_{ij}=\frac{d_id_j}{2m}2m⋅pij​=2mpij​=2mdi​dj​​. As such, the expected number of edges in G′G'G′ is

12∑i∈V∑j∈Vdidj2m=12⋅12m∑i∈Vdi∑j∈Vdj=14m2m⋅2m=m\frac{1}{2}\sum_{i\in V}\sum_{j\in V}\frac{d_id_j}{2m}=\frac{1}{2}\cdot\frac{1}{2m}\sum_{i\in V}d_i\sum_{j\in V}d_j\\=\frac{1}{4m}2m\cdot2m=m21​i∈V∑​j∈V∑​2mdi​dj​​=21​⋅2m1​i∈V∑​di​j∈V∑​dj​=4m1​2m⋅2m=m

Modularity. Putting all together, the Modularity of a partition C\mathcal CC of GGG is

Q(G,C)=12m∑C∈C∑i∈C∑j∈C(aij−didj2m)\mathcal Q(G,\mathcal C)=\frac{1}{2m}\sum_{C\in\mathcal C}\sum_{i\in C}\sum_{j\in C}(a_{ij}-\frac{d_id_j}{2m})Q(G,C)=2m1​C∈C∑​i∈C∑​j∈C∑​(aij​−2mdi​dj​​)

This value is taken in [−1,1][-1,1][−1,1]. A modularity close to 111 indicates a good partition, while a negative value indicates a partition in which connected nodes are separated. A strong community structure is usually considered between Q=0.3\mathcal Q=0.3Q=0.3 and 0.70.70.7,

The direct modularity optimization is NP-hard. The Louvain algorithm propose a greedy algorithm that runs in O(nlog⁡n)\mathcal O(n\log n)O(nlogn). The Louvain method works in a bottom-up fashion by progressively merging the two communities that bring the largest increase in modularity.

Spectral Modularity

A spectral method for modularity maximization.

First, with a bi-partition of the graph i.e. dividing the graph in 2 communities C1,C2C_1,C_2C1​,C2​. Let c∈Rn\mathbf c\in\mathbb R^nc∈Rn be a real vector that indicates whether a node belongs to one or the other community. An entry cic_ici​ is

ci={1 if vi∈C1−1 if vi∈C2c_i=\begin{cases}1\text{ if }v_i\in C_1\\-1\text{ if }v_i\in C_2\end{cases}ci​={1 if vi​∈C1​−1 if vi​∈C2​​

We can rewrite equation for Q\mathcal QQ as

Q=12m∑i,j(aij−didj2m)δ(ci,cj)\mathcal Q=\frac{1}{2m}\sum_{i,j}(a_{ij}-\frac{d_id_j}{2m})\delta(c_i,c_j)Q=2m1​i,j∑​(aij​−2mdi​dj​​)δ(ci​,cj​)

where δ(ci,cj)=1\delta(c_i,c_j)=1δ(ci​,cj​)=1 if ci=cjc_i=c_jci​=cj​ and 000 otherwise.

Notice that δ(ci,cj)=12(cicj+1)\delta(c_i,c_j)=\frac{1}{2}(c_ic_j+1)δ(ci​,cj​)=21​(ci​cj​+1). Thus

Q=14m∑i,j(aij−didj2m)cicj=14mc⊤Bc\mathcal Q=\frac{1}{4m}\sum_{i,j}(a_{ij}-\frac{d_id_j}{2m})c_ic_j=\frac{1}{4m}\mathbf c^\top\mathbf{Bc}Q=4m1​i,j∑​(aij​−2mdi​dj​​)ci​cj​=4m1​c⊤Bc

where B\mathbf BB with entries Bij=aij−didj2mB_{ij}=a_{ij}-\frac{d_id_j}{2m}Bij​=aij​−2mdi​dj​​ is referred to as modularity matrix.

The objective is very close to spectral clustering. However, in this case we try to maximize the quantity. Since B\mathbf BB is symmetric, the variational characterization of the eigenvalues tells that the solution of the optimization max⁡x⊤Mxx⊤x\max\frac{\mathbf x^\top\mathbf{Mx}}{\mathbf x^\top\mathbf x}maxx⊤xx⊤Mx​ is the eigenvector that corresponds to the largest of the eigenvalues of the modularity matrix.

In order to compute the partition c\mathbf cc, we relax the vector c\mathbf cc to take any real value. Our object (omitting 14m1\over4m4m1​) becomes

max⁡cc⊤Bcs.t. c⊤c=n⇒∂∂cc⊤Bc=0⇒∂∂c[c⊤Bc−β(n−c⊤c)]⇒2Bc=2βc\max_\mathbf c \mathbf{c^\top Bc}\\\text{s.t. }\mathbf{c^\top c}=n\\\Rarr\frac{\partial}{\partial\mathbf c}\mathbf{c^\top Bc}=0\\\Rarr\frac{\partial}{\partial\mathbf c}[\mathbf{c^\top Bc}-\beta(n-\mathbf{c^\top c})]\Rarr2\mathbf{Bc}=2\beta ccmax​c⊤Bcs.t. c⊤c=n⇒∂c∂​c⊤Bc=0⇒∂c∂​[c⊤Bc−β(n−c⊤c)]⇒2Bc=2βc

The last equality is an eigenvalue - eigenvalue equation, where β\betaβ is an eigenvalue for the eigenvector c\mathbf cc. If we substitute Bc=βc\mathbf{Bc}=\beta\mathbf cBc=βc, we will obtain

c⊤Bc=c⊤βc=βc⊤c=βn\mathbf{c^\top Bc}=\mathbf{c^\top\beta c}=\beta\mathbf{c^\top c}=\beta nc⊤Bc=c⊤βc=βc⊤c=βn

In order to maximize the objective we need to select the largest eigenvalue and the corresponding eigenvector.

Finally, the partition of the graph is obtained by

ci={1 if vi>0−1 otherwisec_i=\begin{cases}1\text{ if }v_i\gt0\\-1\text{ otherwise}\end{cases}ci​={1 if vi​>0−1 otherwise​

Detecting multiple communities. Similar to spectral clustering, we would be tempted to generalize the spectral modularity to the case of multiple communities by recursive bi-partitioning. This method, however, assumes that the graph is cut into two parts and that the edges among the two partitions are removed. Unfortunately, removing edges changes also the degree of the nodes, and in turns the null model that forms the matrix B\mathbf BB, ending up maximizing the wrong quantity. As a remedy, we consider the change ΔQ\Delta\mathcal QΔQ in modularity after splitting a community CCC into two parts

ΔQ=12m[12∑i,j∈CBij(cicj+1)−∑i,j∈CBij]=14m[∑i,j∈CBijcicj−∑i,j∈CBij]=14m∑i,j∈C[Bij−δij∑k∈CBik]cicj=14mc⊤B(C)c\Delta\mathcal Q=\frac{1}{2m}[\frac{1}{2}\sum_{i,j\in C}B_{ij}(c_ic_j+1)-\sum_{i,j\in C}B_{ij}]\\=\frac{1}{4m}[\sum_{i,j\in C}B_{ij}c_ic_j-\sum_{i,j\in C}B_{ij}]\\=\frac{1}{4m}\sum_{i,j\in C}[B_{ij}-\delta_{ij}\sum_{k\in C}B_{ik}]c_ic_j\\=\frac{1}{4m}\mathbf c^\top \mathbf B^{(C)}\mathbf cΔQ=2m1​[21​i,j∈C∑​Bij​(ci​cj​+1)−i,j∈C∑​Bij​]=4m1​[i,j∈C∑​Bij​ci​cj​−i,j∈C∑​Bij​]=4m1​i,j∈C∑​[Bij​−δij​k∈C∑​Bik​]ci​cj​=4m1​c⊤B(C)c

where δij=1\delta_{ij}=1δij​=1 if i=ji=ji=j and 000 otherwise, is called the Kronecker delta and Bij(C)=Bij−δij∑k∈CBikB_{ij}^{(C)}=B_{ij}-\delta_{ij}\sum_{k\in C}B_{ik}Bij(C)​=Bij​−δij​∑k∈C​Bik​.

The above is generalized spectral method, in which we can repeatedly find eigenvectors in the modified matrix B(C)\mathbf B^{(C)}B(C). It also provides a convenient stopping criteria: Once the increment in modularity is negative, there is no other community that will increase the modularity further and the method can stop.

Pros and Cons

👍

  • Clusters can have arbitrary shape and size, i.e., clusters are not restricted to have convex shapes.
  • Efficient in common real graphs.
  • Robust to noise.

👎

  • Inefficient on dense graphs with O(n3)\mathcal O(n^3)O(n3) in the worse case.
  • Resolution limit: When merging communities if the number of edges is larges.

Overlapping Community Detection

Nodes can be shared among communities. Harder than Non-overlapping.

Clique Percolation

Clique percolation detects overlapping communities by exploiting the definition of clique.

A clique is a fully connected subgraph. In other words, a clique is a set of nodes that have an edge with any other node in the clique.

A kkk-clique is a complete subgraph on kkk nodes.

A kkk-clique is adjacent to another clique if it shares k−1k-1k−1 vertices. In clique percolation we define a community the union of adjacent kkk-cliques. Given such a definition it’s easy to formulate our first algorithm CFinder.

The CFinder algorithm starts with a kkk-clique defining a community, where kkk is a user parameter, and expands the community until there is no more adjacent cliques to add.

Pseudo Code

Input: Graph GGG, Size of cliques kkk

  1. Start with a kkk-clique
  2. Roll the clique over adjacent cliques
  3. A kkk-cliques community is the largest subgraph obtained by the union of all adjacent kkk-cliques
  4. Other kkk-cliques that can not be reached correspond to other clique-communities

Pros and Cons

👍

  • Easy to implement and understand
  • Finding kkk-cliques is polynomial
  • Communities are easily explainable

👎

  • Requires size of cliques: kkk
  • Rigid communities: the results depend on the existence of the cliques.

AGM/BigCLAM

This method instead take a probabilistic approach.

AGM and BigCLAM are two different models but with very similar premises.

Intuition: graph is a sample of an unknown distribution in which we flip a coin on the existence of an edge.

The existence probability is determined by the community structure: the more communities two nodes share, the higher the probability.

Given a graph GGG with communities C\mathcal CC each of them existing with probability pCp_CpC​, a membership set Mi={C∈C∣vi∈C}M_i=\{C\in\mathcal C|v_i\in C\}Mi​={C∈C∣vi​∈C}. The probability of existence of an edge in this model is

P(i,j)=1−∏C∈Mi∩Mj(1−pC)P(i,j)=1-\prod_{C\in M_i\cap M_j}(1-p_C)P(i,j)=1−C∈Mi​∩Mj​∏​(1−pC​)

The above probability ensures that an edge exists if the nodes share at least one community. The above is an instance of a noisy-OR. If the nodes share no community, we assign a fixed small probability ϵ\epsilonϵ.

Our model assumes that each edge is generated independently by any other edge. As such, given the parameters Θ=(C,M,{pC})\Theta=(\mathcal C,M,\{p_C\})Θ=(C,M,{pC​}), the likelihood that our graph GGG is sampled by the AGM model is

P(G∣C,M,{pC})=∏(i,j)∈EP(i,j)∏(i,j)∉E(1−P(i,j))P(G|\mathcal C,M,\{p_C\})=\prod_{(i,j)\in E}P(i,j)\prod_{(i,j)\notin E}(1-P(i,j))P(G∣C,M,{pC​})=(i,j)∈E∏​P(i,j)(i,j)∈/E∏​(1−P(i,j))

AGM is a rather flexible model and can express a variety of community structures, such as non-overlapping and hierarchical communities.

The model assumes that we know already the parameters in order to compute the likelihood of a network.

By maximizing this equation, we can find the parameters of the model that maximize the likelihood. Bit how to find this model? Finding Θ\ThetaΘ means finding a community membership for each node. The task is hard.

From AGM to BigCLAM. AGM model is hard to optimize. BigCLAM drops some of the requirements of AGM to attain efficiency.

Under BigCLAM each node belongs to some community CjC_jCj​ with some strength FijF_{ij}Fij​. If Fij=0F_{ij}=0Fij​=0, node iii is not a member of community jjj. The probability pCp_CpC​ that an edge between iii and jjj exists if they belong to community CCC is

pC(i,j)=1−exp⁡(−FiCFjC).p_C(i,j)=1-\exp(-F_{iC}F_{jC}).pC​(i,j)=1−exp(−FiC​FjC​).

This means that the probability that an edge exists is proportional to the product of the strengths. If one node does not belong to the community CCC (FiC=0F_{iC}=0FiC​=0) then its probability is 000. The probability that at least one common community CCC links two nodes is

P(i,j)=1−∏C(1−pC(i,j))=1−exp⁡(−Fi⋅Fj⋅⊤)P(i,j)=1-\prod_C(1-p_C(i,j))=1-\exp(-\mathbf F_{i\cdot}\mathbf F_{j\cdot}^\top)P(i,j)=1−C∏​(1−pC​(i,j))=1−exp(−Fi⋅​Fj⋅⊤​)

where Fi⋅\mathbf F_{i\cdot}Fi⋅​ is the row vector of the matrix F∈Rn×∣C∣\mathbf F\in\mathbb R^{n\times|C|}F∈Rn×∣C∣.

To compute F\mathbf FF to fit the model to the data, we use a maximum likelihood approach

arg⁡max⁡F∏i,j∈Ep(i,j)∏(i,j)∉E(1−p(i,j)).\arg\max_\mathbf F\prod_{i,j\in E}p(i,j)\prod_{(i,j)\notin E}(1-p(i,j)).argFmax​i,j∈E∏​p(i,j)(i,j)∈/E∏​(1−p(i,j)).

Instead of maximizing the likelihood, we maximize the log-likelihood

P(G∣F)=∑(i,j)∈Elog⁡(1−exp⁡(−Fi⋅Fj⋅⊤))−∑(i,j)∉E(Fi⋅Fj⋅⊤).P(G|\mathbf F)=\sum_{(i,j)\in E}\log(1-\exp(-\mathbf F_{i\cdot}\mathbf F_{j\cdot}^\top))-\sum_{(i,j)\notin E}(\mathbf F_{i\cdot}\mathbf F_{j\cdot}^\top).P(G∣F)=(i,j)∈E∑​log(1−exp(−Fi⋅​Fj⋅⊤​))−(i,j)∈/E∑​(Fi⋅​Fj⋅⊤​).

Since matrix F\mathbf FF is real, the model can be optimized with coordinate ascent over the rows.

Efficiency optimization. The gradient can be optimized by caching and compute an iteration in linear time.

∇P(G∣F)=∑v∈N(i)Fv⋅exp⁡(−Fi⋅Fv⋅⊤))1−exp⁡(−Fi⋅Fv⋅⊤))−∑v∉N(i)Fv.\nabla P(G|\mathbf F)=\sum_{v\in N(i)}\mathbf F_v\cdot\frac{\exp(-\mathbf F_{i\cdot}\mathbf F_{v\cdot}^\top))}{1-\exp(-\mathbf F_{i\cdot}\mathbf F_{v\cdot}^\top))}-\sum_{v\notin N(i)}\mathbf F_v.∇P(G∣F)=v∈N(i)∑​Fv​⋅1−exp(−Fi⋅​Fv⋅⊤​))exp(−Fi⋅​Fv⋅⊤​))​−v∈/N(i)∑​Fv​.

The factor ∑v∉N(i)Fv\sum_{v\notin N(i)}\mathbf F_v∑v∈/N(i)​Fv​ can be written as

∑vFv⋅−Fi⋅−∑v∈N(i)Fv⋅\sum_v\mathbf F_{v\cdot}-\mathbf F_{i\cdot}-\sum_{v\in N(i)}\mathbf F_{v\cdot}v∑​Fv⋅​−Fi⋅​−v∈N(i)∑​Fv⋅​

which runs in linear time as both ∑vFv⋅−Fi⋅\sum_v\mathbf F_{v\cdot}-\mathbf F_{i\cdot}∑v​Fv⋅​−Fi⋅​ can be cashed in advance.

Pros and Cons

👍

  • Detect overlapping and non-overlapping communities
  • Cluster can have arbitrary shapes
  • Nearly linear Complexity
  • Flexible model.

👎

  • Requires the number of communities upfront
  • Hard to find the threshold for determining the membership of each nodes.
entry.summary: Community detection finds sets of nodes, i.e., that are highly connected inside the community and coarsely connected outside the communit

entry.title: 随机算法 7 Dimensionality Reduction
entry.content:
Lecturer: Iannis

Goal of dimensionality reduction: represent a high dimensional data set in a lower dimensional space while preserving much of the important structure.

PCA (principle component analysis): to maintain as much variance in the data as possible while reducing the dimensionality.

The mapping of data from a high dimensional space to a low dimensional space is called an embedding.

Johnson-Lindenstrauss Dimensionality Reduction

Lecture notes by Allan Grønlund

Main results of JL: any mmm point subset of Euclidean space can be linearly embedded in k=O(log⁡m/ϵ2)k=O(\log m/\epsilon^2)k=O(logm/ϵ2) dimensions without distorting the distance between any pair of points by more than a factor of (1±ϵ)(1\pm\epsilon)(1±ϵ), for any 0<ϵ<120\lt\epsilon\lt\frac{1}{2}0<ϵ<21​.

For PCA to be relevant the original data points x1,⋯ ,xmx_1,\cdots,x_mx1​,⋯,xm​ must be inherently low dimensional.

While JL theorem requires no assumption on the original data and the target dimension is even independent of the input dimension.

Further results: JL lemma is tight even for non-linear embeddings.

Simple JL Lemma

Theorem 1. For any 0<ϵ<120\lt\epsilon\lt\frac{1}{2}0<ϵ<21​ and any integer mmm, then for integer

k=O(1ϵ2log⁡m)k=O(\frac{1}{\epsilon^2}\log m)k=O(ϵ21​logm)

large enough and any mmm points x1,⋯ ,xm⊂Rdx_1,\cdots,x_m\subset\mathbb R^dx1​,⋯,xm​⊂Rd there exists a linear map matrix L:Rd→RkL:\mathbb R^d\rarr\mathbb R^kL:Rd→Rk s.t. for any 1≤i,j≤m1\le i,j\le m1≤i,j≤m:

(1−ϵ)∣∣xi−xj∣∣22≤∣∣Lxi−Lxj∣∣22≤(1+ϵ)∣∣xi−xj∣∣22(1-\epsilon)||x_i-x_j||_2^2\le||Lx_i-Lx_j||_2^2\le(1+\epsilon)||x_i-x_j||^2_2(1−ϵ)∣∣xi​−xj​∣∣22​≤∣∣Lxi​−Lxj​∣∣22​≤(1+ϵ)∣∣xi​−xj​∣∣22​

The linear transformation LLL in Theorem 1 is simply multiplication by a matrix whose entries are sampled independently from a standard Gaussian.

Define a random variable AAA as k×dk\times dk×d matrix, where each entry Ai,j∼N(0,1)A_{i,j}\sim\mathcal N(0,1)Ai,j​∼N(0,1). The final embedding matrix is sample of the random variable L=1kAL=\frac{1}{\sqrt k}AL=k​1​A.

First we prove a simply simpler result for such random variables.

Lemma 1. Fix any vector unit vector xxx.

xxx is unit vector if ∑ixi2=1\sum_ix_i^2=1∑i​xi2​=1.

For any 0<ϵ,δ≤120\lt\epsilon,\delta\le\frac{1}{2}0<ϵ,δ≤21​. For k=O(1ϵ2log⁡1δ)k=O(\frac{1}{\epsilon^2}\log\frac{1}{\delta})k=O(ϵ21​logδ1​) large enough let L=1kAL=\frac{1}{\sqrt k}AL=k​1​A be a random variable, where AAA is a k×dk\times dk×d random matrix whose entries are independent ∼N(0,1)\sim\mathcal N(0,1)∼N(0,1). Then:

Pr⁡L(∣∣∣Lx∣∣2−1∣>ϵ)≤δ\Pr_L(|||Lx||^2-1|\gt\epsilon)\le\deltaLPr​(∣∣∣Lx∣∣2−1∣>ϵ)≤δ

If we pick a random matrix as described, then with probability at least 1−δ1-\delta1−δ the norm of xxx is distorted by a factor at most (1±ϵ)(1\pm\epsilon)(1±ϵ) by LLL.

Note that this generalizes to any non-unit vector since a vector vvv can be written as v=∣∣v∣∣v∣∣v∣∣v=||v||\frac{v}{||v||}v=∣∣v∣∣∣∣v∣∣v​. Since the embedding is linear, Lv=∣∣v∣∣Lv∣∣v∣∣Lv=||v||L\frac{v}{||v||}Lv=∣∣v∣∣L∣∣v∣∣v​, thus with probability at least 1−δ1-\delta1−δ,

∣∣Lv∣∣2=∣∣∣∣v∣∣Lv∣∣v∣∣∣∣2=∣∣v∣∣2∣∣Lv∣∣v∣∣∣∣2∈∣∣v∣∣2(1±ϵ)||Lv||^2=\left|\left|||v||L\frac{v}{||v||}\right|\right|^2=||v||^2\left|\left|L\frac{v}{||v||}\right|\right|^2\in||v||^2(1\pm\epsilon)∣∣Lv∣∣2=∣∣∣∣∣​∣∣∣∣∣​∣∣v∣∣L∣∣v∣∣v​∣∣∣∣∣​∣∣∣∣∣​2=∣∣v∣∣2∣∣∣∣∣​∣∣∣∣∣​L∣∣v∣∣v​∣∣∣∣∣​∣∣∣∣∣​2∈∣∣v∣∣2(1±ϵ)

and the same bound applies for any vector vvv.

Proof of Theorem 1

Fix a point set x1,⋯ ,xmx_1,\cdots,x_mx1​,⋯,xm​, Set δ=1m2\delta=\frac{1}{m^2}δ=m21​ and k=O(ϵ−2log⁡1δ)k=O(\epsilon^{-2}\log\frac{1}{\delta})k=O(ϵ−2logδ1​) large enough and consider the random variable matrix L=1kAL=\frac{1}{\sqrt k}AL=k​1​A where Ai,j∼N(0,1)A_{i,j}\sim\mathcal N(0,1)Ai,j​∼N(0,1).

Observation: From linearity of LLL, it follows that ∣∣Lxi−Lxj∣∣=∣∣L(xi−xj)∣∣||Lx_i-Lx_j||=||L(x_i-x_j)||∣∣Lxi​−Lxj​∣∣=∣∣L(xi​−xj​)∣∣. This means that the distance between xix_ixi​ and xjx_jxj​ is distorted by more than (1±ϵ)(1\pm\epsilon)(1±ϵ) iff the norm of the vector (xi−xj)(x_i-x_j)(xi​−xj​) is distorted by more than (1±ϵ)(1\pm\epsilon)(1±ϵ).

Assuming Lemma 1, for any pair of indices i,ji,ji,j, the probability that the matrix LLL distorts the norm of the vector xi−xjx_i-x_jxi​−xj​ by more than (1±ϵ)(1\pm\epsilon)(1±ϵ) is at most δ\deltaδ.

Since we need all pairwise distances to be approximately maintained, we need to bound the probability that there will be at least one index pair i,ji,ji,j s.t. xi−xjx_i-x_jxi​−xj​ is distorted by at least (1±ϵ)(1\pm\epsilon)(1±ϵ). We call an index pair i,ji,ji,j bad if LLL does not maintain the norm of xi−xjx_i-x_jxi​−xj​.

Applying the Union Bound, the probability over LLL that there is a bad index pair is at most the sum over all i,ji,ji,j the probability that LLL distorts the norm of xi−xjx_i-x_jxi​−xj​ by more than (1±ϵ)(1\pm\epsilon)(1±ϵ). We get:

Pr⁡L(∃(i,j) that is bad)≤∑i=1m−1∑j=i+1mPr⁡((i,j) bad)=(m2)1m3≤1m\Pr_L(\exist(i,j)\text{ that is bad})\le\sum_{i=1}^{m-1}\sum_{j=i+1}^m\Pr((i,j)\text{ bad})=\left(\begin{array}{cc}m\\2\end{array}\right)\frac{1}{m^3}\le\frac{1}{m}LPr​(∃(i,j) that is bad)≤i=1∑m−1​j=i+1∑m​Pr((i,j) bad)=(m2​)m31​≤m1​

Thus with probability at least 1−1m>01-\frac{1}{m}\gt01−m1​>0 the random matrix LLL maintains all the pairwise norms in the dataset within a factor (1±ϵ)(1\pm\epsilon)(1±ϵ). In particular, this means that there exists a matrix that can embed the points and maintain all pairwise distances and to find one just sample a matrix and it works with probability at least 1−1m1-\frac{1}{m}1−m1​.

It remains to prove Lemma 1.

Fact 1. Fir any constants a,ba,ba,b, if X∼N(0,1),Y∼N(0,1)X\sim\mathcal N(0,1),Y\sim\mathcal N(0,1)X∼N(0,1),Y∼N(0,1), then aX+bY∼(0,a2σx2+b2σy2)aX+bY\sim(0,a^2\sigma_x^2+b^2\sigma_y^2)aX+bY∼(0,a2σx2​+b2σy2​).

Chi-square distribution: the sum of square of kkk independent random variables which ∼N(0,1)\sim\mathcal N(0,1)∼N(0,1)

Lemma 2. Let Y∼χk2Y\sim\chi_k^2Y∼χk2​. Then

Pr⁡Y(∣Yk−1∣≥x)≤exp⁡(−316kx2),x∈[0,12)\Pr_Y\left(\left|\frac{Y}{k}-1\right|\ge x\right)\le\exp\left(-\frac{3}{16}kx^2\right),x\in[0,\frac{1}{2})YPr​(∣∣∣∣∣​kY​−1∣∣∣∣∣​≥x)≤exp(−163​kx2),x∈[0,21​)

First we prove that the random variable defined as the norm of ∣∣Ax∣∣2||Ax||^2∣∣Ax∣∣2 is χk2\chi_k^2χk2​ distributed. The we apply Lemma 2 and Lemma 1.

Lemma 3. Given any unit vector x∈Rdx\in\mathbb R^dx∈Rd. Let AAA be the random variable matrix with each Ai,j∼N(0,1)A_{i,j}\sim\mathcal N(0,1)Ai,j​∼N(0,1) independently of the other entries. Then the random variable that is the squared norm of AxAxAx is χk,d\chi_{k,d}χk,d​ distributed:

∣∣Ax∣∣2∼χk2||Ax||^2\sim\chi_k^2∣∣Ax∣∣2∼χk2​

Let aia_iai​ denote the iii-th row of AAA:

∣∣Ax∣∣2=∑i=1k⟨ai,x⟩2=∑i=1k(∑j=1dai,jxj)2.||Ax||^2=\sum_{i=1}^k\langle a_i,x\rangle^2=\sum_{i=1}^k\left(\sum_{j=1}^da_{i,j}x_j\right)^2.∣∣Ax∣∣2=i=1∑k​⟨ai​,x⟩2=i=1∑k​(j=1∑d​ai,j​xj​)2.

By Fact 1, ai,j∼N(0,1)a_{i,j}\sim\mathcal N(0,1)ai,j​∼N(0,1), we know ai,jxj∼N(0,xj2)a_{i,j}x_j\sim\mathcal N(0,x_j^2)ai,j​xj​∼N(0,xj2​) and we are computing a sum of these. This means that ∑j=1dai,jxj∼N(0,∑j=1dxj2)=N(0,1)\sum_{j=1}^da_{i,j}x_j\sim\mathcal N(0,\sum_{j=1}^dx_j^2)=\mathcal N(0,1)∑j=1d​ai,j​xj​∼N(0,∑j=1d​xj2​)=N(0,1), since ∣∣x∣∣2=1||x||^2=1∣∣x∣∣2=1. In total, we get that ∣∣Ax∣∣2||Ax||^2∣∣Ax∣∣2 is distributed as a sum of kkk standard Gaussians i.e.

∣∣Ax∣∣2∼∑i=1kN(0,1)2∼χk2||Ax||^2\sim\sum_{i=1}^k\mathcal N(0,1)^2\sim\chi_k^2∣∣Ax∣∣2∼i=1∑k​N(0,1)2∼χk2​

Proof of Lemma 1

Fix a unit vector xxx and consider the random variable matrix L=1kAL=\frac{1}{\sqrt k}AL=k​1​A defined as usual.

First note that the expected value E[∣∣Ax∣∣2]=k\mathbb E[||Ax||^2]=kE[∣∣Ax∣∣2]=k, which means that E[∣∣Lx∣∣2]=1\mathbb E[||Lx||^2]=1E[∣∣Lx∣∣2]=1, i.e., in expectation the norm of xxx is preserved by LLL. This is a very relevant property indeed. But not enough.

We need to argue that

Pr⁡L(∣∣∣Lx∣∣2−1∣>ϵ)≤δ\Pr_L(|||Lx||^2-1|\gt\epsilon)\le\deltaLPr​(∣∣∣Lx∣∣2−1∣>ϵ)≤δ

Luckily this is exactly captured in Lemma 2. Since ∣∣Ax∣∣2∼χk2||Ax||^2\sim\chi_k^2∣∣Ax∣∣2∼χk2​, then

Pr⁡A(∣∣∣Ax∣∣2k−1∣≥ϵ)≤exp⁡(−316kϵ2),\Pr_A\left(\left|\frac{||Ax||^2}{k}-1\right|\ge\epsilon\right)\le\exp\left(-\frac{3}{16}k\epsilon^2\right),APr​(∣∣∣∣∣​k∣∣Ax∣∣2​−1∣∣∣∣∣​≥ϵ)≤exp(−163​kϵ2),

since ∣∣Ax∣∣2/k=∣∣1kAx∣∣2=∣∣Lx∣∣2||Ax||^2/k=||\frac{1}{\sqrt k}Ax||^2=||Lx||^2∣∣Ax∣∣2/k=∣∣k​1​Ax∣∣2=∣∣Lx∣∣2, this means that

Pr⁡L(∣∣∣Lx∣∣2−1∣>ϵ)≤exp⁡(−316kϵ2).\Pr_L(|||Lx||^2-1|\gt\epsilon)\le\exp\left(-\frac{3}{16}k\epsilon^2\right).LPr​(∣∣∣Lx∣∣2−1∣>ϵ)≤exp(−163​kϵ2).

To finalize the proof, we need to find a kkk s.t. exp⁡(−316kϵ2)\exp(-\frac{3}{16}k\epsilon^2)exp(−163​kϵ2) which is easily achieved by setting k≥163ϵ−2log⁡1δk\ge\frac{16}{3}\epsilon^{-2}\log\frac{1}{\delta}k≥316​ϵ−2logδ1​.

Remarks

JL Lemma generalizes to the case where the entries in AAA are instead uniform random signs ±1\pm1±1. Also, it can be shown that the matrix can be made sparse and the amount of randomness required reduced, all steps to make the embedding more efficient.

We can reduce the dimensionality of any dataset by using a simple randomized linear transformation.

But what if we allow non-linear embedding? Amazed: We can’t!

JL embedding lemma is tight even for non-linear embeddings by showing that there exists data set s.t. there is no way to embed into a space with lower dimension than what is promised in the JL Lemma without violating some of the pairwise distances.

Application on K-Means

lecture notes by Kasper

K-Means

To compute kkk centers minimizing the sum of distances each point to its nearest cluster center.

Computing the optimal k-means is NP-hard. So we use heuristic algorithm such as Lloyd’s algorithm.

The Lloyd’s algorithm starts by partitioning the input points into kkk clusters X1,⋯ ,XkX_1,\cdots,X_kX1​,⋯,Xk​ in some way. Repeat: compute the optimal cluster centers, then reassign each point to the cluster center and repeat until no clusters change.

This algorithm may get stuck in a local minimum and depend on initialization.

Let ttt denote the number of iterations, the total running time is O(tndk)O(tndk)O(tndk)

  • ttt iterations
  • compute new clusters in O(nd)O(nd)O(nd) time
  • reassign points in O(ndk)O(ndk)O(ndk) time.

Applying Johnson-Lindenstrauss

To speed up Lloyd’s algorithm

Before running Lloyd’s algorithm, perform a JL transform s.t. all distances between points are preserved to within (1±ϵ)(1\pm\epsilon)(1±ϵ).

Let A∈Rm×dA\in\mathbb R^{m\times d}A∈Rm×d be the embedding matrix s.t. each original point xix_ixi​ is mapped to AxiAx_iAxi​. The new dimensionality is m=O(ϵ−2log⁡n)m=O(\epsilon^{-2}\log n)m=O(ϵ−2logn). Performing the transform takes O(ndϵ−2log⁡n)O(nd\epsilon^{-2}\log n)O(ndϵ−2logn) time, which may be much less than O(tdnk)O(tdnk)O(tdnk). Therefore, running Lloyd’s in the lower dimensional space takes tnkϵ−2log⁡ntnk\epsilon^{-2}\log ntnkϵ−2logn for a total running time of O(nϵ−2(d+kt)log⁡n)O(n\epsilon^{-2}(d+kt)\log n)O(nϵ−2(d+kt)logn).

Lemma 4. For any set of points x1,⋯ ,xnx_1,\cdots,x_nx1​,⋯,xn​ and a partitioning of the points into clusters X1,⋯ ,XkX_1,\cdots,X_kX1​,⋯,Xk​, the cost of the clustering satisfies

∑j=1k∑xi∈Xj∣∣xi−1∣Xj∣∑xh∈Xjxh∣∣22=12∑j=1k1∣Xj∣∑xi∈Xj∑xh∈Xj∣∣xi−xh∣∣22\sum_{j=1}^k\sum_{x_i\in X_j}\left|\left|x_i-\frac{1}{|X_j|}\sum_{x_h\in X_j}x_h\right|\right|_2^2=\frac{1}{2}\sum_{j=1}^k\frac{1}{|X_j|}\sum_{x_i\in X_j}\sum_{x_h\in X_j}||x_i-x_h||_2^2j=1∑k​xi​∈Xj​∑​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​xi​−∣Xj​∣1​xh​∈Xj​∑​xh​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​22​=21​j=1∑k​∣Xj​∣1​xi​∈Xj​∑​xh​∈Xj​∑​∣∣xi​−xh​∣∣22​

The interesting thing about Lemma 4 is that it shows that the cost of a clustering can be written solely in terms of pairwise distances. This means that the cost of all clusterings will be roughly preserved if all distances are roughly preserved.

Consider any clustering X1,⋯ ,XkX_1,\cdots,X_kX1​,⋯,Xk​ on the dimensionality reduced data set Ax1,⋯ ,AxnAx_1,\cdots,Ax_nAx1​,⋯,Axn​ and assume its cost is μ\muμ. By lemma 4, we get that the cost of the clustering equals

∑j=1k∑xi∈Xj∣∣Axi−1∣Xj∣∑xh∈XjAxh∣∣22=12∑j=1k1∣Xj∣∑xi∈Xj∑xh∈Xj∣∣Axi−Axh∣∣22\sum_{j=1}^k\sum_{x_i\in X_j}\left|\left|Ax_i-\frac{1}{|X_j|}\sum_{x_h\in X_j}Ax_h\right|\right|_2^2=\frac{1}{2}\sum_{j=1}^k\frac{1}{|X_j|}\sum_{x_i\in X_j}\sum_{x_h\in X_j}||Ax_i-Ax_h||_2^2j=1∑k​xi​∈Xj​∑​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​Axi​−∣Xj​∣1​xh​∈Xj​∑​Axh​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​22​=21​j=1∑k​∣Xj​∣1​xi​∈Xj​∑​xh​∈Xj​∑​∣∣Axi​−Axh​∣∣22​

JL guarantees that each term ∣∣Axi−Axh∣∣22||Ax_i-Ax_h||_2^2∣∣Axi​−Axh​∣∣22​ is within (1±ϵ)∣∣xi−xh∣∣22(1\pm\epsilon)||x_i-x_h||_2^2(1±ϵ)∣∣xi​−xh​∣∣22​, thus the cost of same clustering on the original data points lies in the interval:

12∑j=1k1∣Xj∣∑xi∈Xj∑xh∈Xj(1±ϵ)∣∣xi−xh∣∣22=(1±ϵ)μ.\frac{1}{2}\sum_{j=1}^k\frac{1}{|X_j|}\sum_{x_i\in X_j}\sum_{x_h\in X_j}(1\pm\epsilon)||x_i-x_h||_2^2=(1\pm\epsilon)\mu.21​j=1∑k​∣Xj​∣1​xi​∈Xj​∑​xh​∈Xj​∑​(1±ϵ)∣∣xi​−xh​∣∣22​=(1±ϵ)μ.

Since this holds for all clusterings, we can in particular conclude that if one finds a good clustering on the low dimensional data set (say one with a cost of at most (1+γ)μ∗(1+\gamma)\mu^*(1+γ)μ∗ where μ∗\mu^*μ∗ is the optimal clustering in low dimensional space), then that clustering has a cost of at most (1+ϵ)(1+γ)μ∗(1+\epsilon)(1+\gamma)\mu^*(1+ϵ)(1+γ)μ∗ on the original data set.

Moreover, if we let ψ∗\psi^*ψ∗ be the cost of the optimal clustering X∗X^*X∗ on the original data set, then we know that the optimal clustering must have a cost of 11±ϵψ∗≥μ∗\frac{1}{1\pm\epsilon}\psi^*\ge\mu^*1±ϵ1​ψ∗≥μ∗ in low dimensional space. It follows that the clustering XXX has a cost of no more than (1+ϵ)(1+γ)11±ϵψ∗(1+\epsilon)(1+\gamma)\frac{1}{1\pm\epsilon}\psi^*(1+ϵ)(1+γ)1±ϵ1​ψ∗. For ϵ<12\epsilon\lt\frac{1}{2}ϵ<21​, we have 1/(1−ϵ)=1+ϵ(1−ϵ)≤1+2ϵ1/(1-\epsilon)=1+\epsilon(1-\epsilon)\le1+2\epsilon1/(1−ϵ)=1+ϵ(1−ϵ)≤1+2ϵ and (1+ϵ)(1+2ϵ)=(1+3ϵ+2ϵ2)≤1+4ϵ(1+\epsilon)(1+2\epsilon)=(1+3\epsilon+2\epsilon^2)\le1+4\epsilon(1+ϵ)(1+2ϵ)=(1+3ϵ+2ϵ2)≤1+4ϵ and thus the cost is no more than (1+4ϵ)(1+γ)ψ∗(1+4\epsilon)(1+\gamma)\psi^*(1+4ϵ)(1+γ)ψ∗. That is, if we can find an approximately optimal clustering for the dimensionality reduced points, we have found an approximately optimal clustering for the original points.

Proof of Lemma 4

∑j=1k∑xi∈Xj∣∣xi−1∣Xj∣∑xh∈Xjxh∣∣22=∑j=1k∑xi∈Xj(∣∣xi∣∣2−2∣Xj∣∑xh∈Xj⟨xi,xh⟩+1∣Xj∣2∣∣∑xh∈Xjxh∣∣22)=∑j=1k(∑xi∈Xj∣∣xi∣∣22−2∣Xj∣⟨∑xi∈Xjxi,∑xh∈Xjxh⟩+1∣Xj∣∣∣∑xh∈Xjxh∣∣22)=∑j=1k(∑xi∈Xj∣∣xi∣∣22−2∣Xj∣∣∣∑xi∈Xj∣∣22+1∣Xj∣∣∣∑xh∈Xjxh∣∣22)=∑j=1k(∑xi∈Xj∣∣xi∣∣22−1∣Xj∣∣∣∑xi∈Xjxi∣∣22)=12∑j=1k(2∑xi∈Xj∣∣xi∣∣22−2∣Xj∣∣∣∑xi∈Xjxi∣∣22)=12∑j=1k(2∣Xj∣∑xi∈Xj∑xh∈Xj∣∣xi∣∣22−2∣Xj∣∑xi∈Xj∑xh∈Xj⟨xi,xh⟩)=12∑j=1k(1∣Xj∣∑xi∈Xj∑xh∈Xj(∣∣xi∣∣22+∣∣xh∣∣22)−2∣Xj∣∑xi∈Xj∑xh∈Xh⟨Xi,xj⟩)=12∑j=1k1∣Xj∣∑xi∈Xj∑xh∈Xj(∣∣xi∣∣22+∣∣xh∣∣22−2⟨xi,xh⟩)=12∑j=1k1∣Xj∣∑xi∈Xj∑xh∈Xj∣∣xi−xh∣∣22\sum_{j=1}^k\sum_{x_i\in X_j}\left|\left|x_i-\frac{1}{|X_j|}\sum_{x_h\in X_j}x_h\right|\right|_2^2\\=\sum_{j=1}^k\sum_{x_i\in X_j}\left(||x_i||^2-\frac{2}{|X_j|}\sum_{x_h\in X_j}\langle x_i,x_h\rangle+\frac{1}{|X_j|^2}||\sum_{x_h\in X_j}x_h||_2^2\right)\\=\sum_{j=1}^k\left(\sum_{x_i\in X_j}||x_i||_2^2-\frac{2}{|X_j|}\langle\sum_{x_i\in X_j}x_i,\sum_{x_h\in X_j}x_h\rangle+\frac{1}{|X_j|}||\sum_{x_h\in X_j}x_h||_2^2\right)\\=\sum_{j=1}^k\left(\sum_{x_i\in X_j}||x_i||_2^2-\frac{2}{|X_j|}||\sum_{x_i\in X_j}||_2^2+\frac{1}{|X_j|}||\sum_{x_h\in X_j}x_h||_2^2\right)\\=\sum_{j=1}^k\left(\sum_{x_i\in X_j}||x_i||_2^2-\frac{1}{|X_j|}||\sum_{x_i\in X_j}x_i||_2^2\right)\\=\frac{1}{2}\sum_{j=1}^k\left(2\sum_{x_i\in X_j}||x_i||_2^2-\frac{2}{|X_j|}||\sum_{x_i\in X_j}x_i||_2^2\right)\\=\frac{1}{2}\sum_{j=1}^k\left(\frac{2}{|X_j|}\sum_{x_i\in X_j}\sum_{x_h\in X_j}||x_i||_2^2-\frac{2}{|X_j|}\sum_{x_i\in X_j}\sum_{x_h\in X_j}\langle x_i,x_h\rangle\right)\\=\frac{1}{2}\sum_{j=1}^k\left(\frac{1}{|X_j|}\sum_{x_i\in X_j}\sum_{x_h\in X_j}(||x_i||_2^2+||x_h||_2^2)-\frac{2}{|X_j|}\sum_{x_i\in X_j}\sum_{x_h\in X_h}\langle X_i,x_j\rangle\right)\\=\frac{1}{2}\sum_{j=1}^k\frac{1}{|X_j|}\sum_{x_i\in X_j}\sum_{x_h\in X_j}(||x_i||_2^2+||x_h||_2^2-2\langle x_i,x_h\rangle)\\=\frac{1}{2}\sum_{j=1}^k\frac{1}{|X_j|}\sum_{x_i\in X_j}\sum_{x_h\in X_j}||x_i-x_h||_2^2j=1∑k​xi​∈Xj​∑​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​xi​−∣Xj​∣1​xh​∈Xj​∑​xh​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​22​=j=1∑k​xi​∈Xj​∑​⎝⎛​∣∣xi​∣∣2−∣Xj​∣2​xh​∈Xj​∑​⟨xi​,xh​⟩+∣Xj​∣21​∣∣xh​∈Xj​∑​xh​∣∣22​⎠⎞​=j=1∑k​⎝⎛​xi​∈Xj​∑​∣∣xi​∣∣22​−∣Xj​∣2​⟨xi​∈Xj​∑​xi​,xh​∈Xj​∑​xh​⟩+∣Xj​∣1​∣∣xh​∈Xj​∑​xh​∣∣22​⎠⎞​=j=1∑k​⎝⎛​xi​∈Xj​∑​∣∣xi​∣∣22​−∣Xj​∣2​∣∣xi​∈Xj​∑​∣∣22​+∣Xj​∣1​∣∣xh​∈Xj​∑​xh​∣∣22​⎠⎞​=j=1∑k​⎝⎛​xi​∈Xj​∑​∣∣xi​∣∣22​−∣Xj​∣1​∣∣xi​∈Xj​∑​xi​∣∣22​⎠⎞​=21​j=1∑k​⎝⎛​2xi​∈Xj​∑​∣∣xi​∣∣22​−∣Xj​∣2​∣∣xi​∈Xj​∑​xi​∣∣22​⎠⎞​=21​j=1∑k​⎝⎛​∣Xj​∣2​xi​∈Xj​∑​xh​∈Xj​∑​∣∣xi​∣∣22​−∣Xj​∣2​xi​∈Xj​∑​xh​∈Xj​∑​⟨xi​,xh​⟩⎠⎞​=21​j=1∑k​⎝⎛​∣Xj​∣1​xi​∈Xj​∑​xh​∈Xj​∑​(∣∣xi​∣∣22​+∣∣xh​∣∣22​)−∣Xj​∣2​xi​∈Xj​∑​xh​∈Xh​∑​⟨Xi​,xj​⟩⎠⎞​=21​j=1∑k​∣Xj​∣1​xi​∈Xj​∑​xh​∈Xj​∑​(∣∣xi​∣∣22​+∣∣xh​∣∣22​−2⟨xi​,xh​⟩)=21​j=1∑k​∣Xj​∣1​xi​∈Xj​∑​xh​∈Xj​∑​∣∣xi​−xh​∣∣22​

Lecturer: Iannis

Goal of dimensionality reduction: represent a high dimensional data set in a lower dimensional space while preser
